151327387.review:
A Divine Descent into Darkness:

Blasphemous, developed by The Game Kitchen, is a dark and atmospheric action-platformer that plunges players into a nightmarish world inspired by Spanish folklore and religious iconography. Released in 2019, this 2D side-scrolling game has garnered attention for its challenging gameplay, haunting visuals, and a narrative steeped in themes of redemption and penance.

One of the standout features of Blasphemous is its intricate and atmospheric world design. The game unfolds in the nightmarish land of Cvstodia, a place cursed by grotesque creatures and plagued by the echoes of a mysterious, divine calamity. The pixel art is stunning, bringing to life the twisted landscapes, eerie dungeons, and grotesque enemies in a way that is both horrifying and captivating. The attention to detail in the art contributes significantly to the overall immersion, making each area a visual feast for players willing to explore the unsettling depths of Cvstodia.

The gameplay is equally compelling, combining precise combat mechanics with challenging platforming elements. Players take control of The Penitent One, a silent and stoic protagonist on a quest for redemption in a world brimming with macabre adversaries. The combat system is punishing but rewarding, encouraging players to learn enemy patterns and master the use of a variety of weapons and special abilities. The level of difficulty may be a deterrent for some, but for those seeking a true test of skill, Blasphemous delivers an experience that is as unforgiving as the world it portrays.

The narrative is presented through cryptic environmental storytelling, religious symbolism, and haunting NPC interactions. The lore is deep and mysterious, with a narrative that unfolds gradually as players progress through the punishing landscapes. The themes of guilt, redemption, and atonement are woven into the fabric of the game, adding emotional weight to the dark journey of The Penitent One.

While the game has received praise for its atmospheric design and challenging gameplay, some players may find the difficulty level to be a double-edged sword. The unforgiving nature of the combat can be frustrating for those not accustomed to demanding experiences, potentially limiting the game's appeal to a specific audience.

In conclusion, Blasphemous is a masterclass in atmospheric design and challenging gameplay, offering a haunting journey through a nightmarish world. The combination of pixel-perfect art, punishing combat, and a deep narrative make it a standout title for fans of dark and atmospheric action-platformers. However, its high difficulty may be a barrier for some players, making it more suitable for those who relish a challenging and immersive gaming experience.

151120131.review:
Blasphemous es un videojuego de Metroidvania desarrollado por el estudio español The Game Kitchen y publicado por Team17[4]. Este juego ha sido elogiado por la crítica y los jugadores por su ambiente aterrador y su estilo de juego desafiante. A continuación, se presentan algunos aspectos destacados del juego:

- **Arte y estética**: Blasphemous cuenta con un arte impresionante en forma de pixel, que le confiere un aspecto retro, pero con animaciones detalladas que se asemejan a las modernas. El juego tiene una atmósfera sombría y melancólica que recuerda a los clásicos Castlevania, con un ambiente lleno de sangre y sadismo[5].

- **Historia y personajes**: La trama se centra en un personaje conocido como The Penitent One, quien se encuentra rodeado de un montón de cadáveres con cascos similares en la parte superior de los restos humanos. La historia es narrada a través de instrucciones riddle-like entregadas por un personaje llamado Deogracias, quien es el testigo del "Milagro Grievioso"[5].

- **Juego**: Blasphemous es un juego de 2D Metroidvania con un estilo de juego no lineal. Los jugadores pueden explorar diferentes áreas de manera no lineal y encontrar varios puntos de control "Prie-Dieus" en el estilo de Dark Souls. El combate es desafiante y requiere de evasiones frecuentes y parrias bien timadas[5].

- **Dificultad**: El juego es conocido por su dificultad, lo que puede resultar en una experiencia de juego que puede resultar en frustración para algunos jugadores. Sin embargo, también ha sido elogiado por su capacidad de crear una atmósfera aterradora y desafiante[5].

En resumen, Blasphemous es un videojuego que se destaca por su arte impresionante, su ambiente aterrador y su estilo de juego desafiante. A pesar de su dificultad, el juego ha sido elogiado por la crítica y los jugadores por su capacidad de crear una experiencia única y emocionante. Felicitaciones a los desarrolladores por su trabajo en este juego inolvidable.

Es una experiencia donde la espiritualidad, la estética y la música se entrelazan magistralmente para crear un viaje inolvidable a través de la penitencia y la redención.

150460132.review:
I rarely write reviews for games, but this one was just that good. 

The combat has a learning curve, but when it clicks you fall in love with it. The combat is seriously grate. Platforming can be tricky, but it is a staple of the genre after all.

The world is masterfully interconnected, so backtracking rarely felt like a chore, which makes for a great Metroidvania experience.

The plot, setting, visual design, art and soundtrack are all 10/10. I haven't played something this engaging in a while, I was and still am super intrigued to learn more about Cvstodia. I played the game in Spanish with English subtitles and I feel like it definitely enhanced my experience.

Overall, I wholeheartedly recommend this game. Don't get scared by the difficulty - persevere and enjoy the experience!

150371650.review:
Blasphemous is a captivating and brutal gaming experience, that combines the world design, atmospheric music and a unique storytelling in a good way.
The moment you enter the world of Cvstodia you're confronted with a dark and haunting reality that makes you keep exploring its depths. One of the standout features in Blasphemous is the world design. The landscapes are beautifully crafted, and have an incredible attention to detail, and some very challenging parts. The boss battles are a balance between challenge and fairness. The difficulty seems a bit lower compared to other games in this genre. 
Blasphemous has a unique storytelling approach. It invites the player to piece together the lore and history of Cvstodia through item descriptions and talking to NPCs. What makes Blasphemous truly stand out is its sheer brutality. The game embraces a visceral and bloody aesthetic. The concept of Pain is central to the experience, creating a world that is both disturbing and oddly satisfying. It is, in my opinion, what makes the game most memorable.
Overall, I'd say the game is definitely worth a try and another top game on my Souls-Like list

IF you ever played hollow knight, this is the exact opposite.
The controls are SO unresponsive. And they make the platforming and the enemies in ways that dont make it hard, but annoying to play.
You will keep falling to death because the character didn't grab to a ledge out of the blue.
Or because an enemy is put in a location that is annoying to avoid.
And most enemies are so easy, but have some super slow attack animation you have to wait out for, forcing you to stop and slow down the gameplay at every, single, darn, mob.
It is excruciatingly slow paced, and as soon as you get out of the "first hour" the platforming and enemies become especially annoying instead of harder.

I got this on a discount and played a few hours in already, so no refund for me anymore. But if I could, I'd still ask for a refund. Pretty sure I wont continue playing this.

The story really feels interesting, but so far nothing really made sense. Maybe the story opens up over time, but I got a feeling this will be one of those "dont expect to understand anything, its misterious" kind of stories that never explain or make sense of anything from start to finish.

The artwork is really nice.

150030985.review:
Blasphemous is a mesmerizing journey into a nightmarish world of pixelated beauty and relentless challenge. From the hauntingly atmospheric soundtrack to the meticulously crafted environments, every aspect of this game is a testament to the developers' commitment to delivering a truly unforgettable experience.

The combat in Blasphemous is nothing short of brutal, demanding precise timing and strategic thinking. Each swing of your weapon feels weighty and satisfying, and every encounter with the grotesque foes is a test of skill and patience. The game's punishing difficulty may not be for everyone, but for those seeking a true test of their gaming prowess, Blasphemous delivers in spades.

The narrative is as dark and cryptic as the pixelated landscapes you traverse, drawing you deeper into a macabre lore filled with religious symbolism and grim folklore. The interconnected world is a joy to explore, filled with secrets, challenging platforming sections, and horrifyingly imaginative enemies.

While the difficulty may be a barrier for some, the sense of accomplishment that comes with conquering each challenging area is incredibly rewarding. Blasphemous is a masterclass in atmospheric storytelling, punishing gameplay, and pixel artistry that will leave a lasting impression on anyone daring enough to delve into its nightmarish depths. Highly recommended for fans of challenging action-platformers with a taste for the macabre.

uninteresting game, far to difficult, terrible controls, gave up before I wasted too much time on this ms paint game.

I know what its trying to do, its trying to be a certain type of vania on a certain type of poorly lit souls, but I refuse to type the proper terms in to give this offering the proper search keywords

it favours difficulty over anything else, and thats not a hole i'm going to go down at all these days, so its a fault right there

The controls, and there are many of them, suffers from the same fault all games have when they have 10 controls, and that is "what button to press" If I need to jump, what results is a button press mashing event every 20-30 seconds to find the desired control and play with it. 

It does keep the same ability to 'just run past the enemies', but I dont know what i'm running to

There may be loads of lore and story, but after just under an hour of play, I was not aware of any of it, nor would I care about it, its  just a retro game of uninteresting response from me, which is a shame, as i'm sure its someone tried really hard to make a VGA game for the current 202x age, but just didnt decide to make it fun to play, rather than rely on the meme of difficulty over 'gud'

old gameplay memes like "the monsters respawn after you rest at the holy bonfire" just makes my heart sink of another pointless gameplay element intended to lengthen the time taken to get from point A to point B. DS2 had a novel twist on this, which I am not going to explain what this was, as it would alleviate required research, but it was reversed with the bonfire pumpkin. That novel addition made the game at least playable and the grinding was rewarded. I'm not sure if such a mechanic exists in "BS" but no information was given, its not going to get found out. 

The same attribute on death also applies to the little sliver of theft to the players "MP" bar. I dont know if BS calls it something else, if it did it was forgettable, so its the "MP" bar.  Why? why tf does the game have to steal this asset from me when the player dies due to bad gameplay and level concepts? I did not agree to this. it feels so cheap when the game stoops so low to ideas attempted and done and tried before. Why can't the game have something new and novel in it for a new gameplay experience 

no. I have places to be. 1/10

149919030.review:
If I had to pick two words to describe this game, they would be [b] clunky [/b] and [b] inconsistent [/b].  
  
When comparing this game to other metroidvanias, it's fairly mediocre if not on the lower end, Clunky combat, inconsistent hitboxes, long runbacks due to platforming fails because of the inconsistent hitboxes, and overall a lack of respect for the player's time. There is a lot of platforming, but Blasphemous sucks the fun out of what's normally one of the most fun parts of these games; the slightest error results in instant death and a long runback, and oftentimes that "error" is you phasing through a platform, falling right past a grabbable ledge, hitting an invisible spike hitbox, falling through a ladder that you pressed the button to interact with, etc.

And the hitboxes? Forget them corresponding in any way to your character sprite or those of the enemies. There are some instance where this works in the player's favor with an attack harmlessly slicing right through you, but generally it just leaves you thinking "how the hell did that hit me?" And that's not to mention that the hitstun on everything has no rhyme or reason. Some sources of damage (particularly with respect to platforming) will give you a long stun if you're grounded when hit and none if you're airborne when hit, some have hitstun that can be cancelled by crouching, and others will always knock you back a seemingly random distance each time. The thing is, there's no consistency to it.

I completed the game (endings A and B) and did all the blue rose challenges, and, quite honestly, I regret putting the time into this game.

If you haven't played Hollow Knight, you'd be much better off playing it than playing this. If you have played Hollow Knight and enjoyed it, you probably won't have much patience for this game's pitfalls. This game has potential, but it would require a lot more polish for me to recommend it for anyone.

149643388.review:
[h1]Frustratingly Obtuse and Unnecessarily Challenging[/h1]


Blasphemous is a game that seems to revel in its own obscurity and difficulty, [b]often at the expense of player enjoyment[/b]. While the game boasts stunning pixel art and a captivating atmosphere, it's marred by[b] frustrating-level design[/b], [b]unclear objectives[/b], and an [b]excessive amount of backtracking[/b].


From the outset, the game throws you into the depths of its unforgiving world [b]without much explanation or guidance[/b]. The map, while aesthetically pleasing, lacks clarity and often leads to confusion and frustration. The game's reliance on cryptic clues and hidden paths makes it [b]feel more like a punishment[/b] than a rewarding exploration.


The combat system, while initially engaging, quickly [b]becomes repetitive and lacks depth[/b]. [b]Enemies are easily dispatched[/b] with basic attacks, and bosses, while visually impressive, follow predictable patterns that make them more [b]tedious than challenging[/b].


The game's true frustration lies in its [b]excessive amount of backtracking[/b]. Progress often requires collecting scattered items or completing convoluted tasks, forcing players to trudge through the same [b]familiar areas repeatedly[/b]. This repetitive nature makes the game [b]feel like a chore[/b] rather than an enjoyable experience.


While the game's art style is undeniably impressive, its dark and gritty aesthetic can become overwhelming after extended play sessions. The oppressive atmosphere and constant barrage of grotesque imagery can make it [b]difficult to maintain interest and motivation[/b].


Overall, Blasphemous is a game that seems to prioritize difficulty and obscurity over accessibility and enjoyment. While it may appeal to those seeking a punishing challenge, its flaws outweigh its strengths, making it a frustrating and unrewarding experience for many players.

POV: You play the game, you love it.
It's extremely satisfying, and you end up fighting the final boss at a neat 98% of completion.
You play the whole thing by yourself, exploring the whole amazing world without looking at guides or similar, you don't want to ruin your experience.
You start wondering where's the DLCs who have been released and would expand the game, maybe giving you neat bosses and crazy ass story bits.
You discover that the juicy DLC content and true finale can be only obtained by playing the whole thing again through NewGame+,and doing extremely specific things that radically change the flow of the story.
But why not giving me the choice of doing this after finishing the game?
Why do I have to restart and play the whole thing again?
I feel betrayed, I feel like uninstalling.

I won't restart the game, I won't fight the neat bosses.

Guys, on the DLC, you fucked up HARD.

149608731.review:
Did you love Castlevania SOTN? If so, play Blasphemous. It totally captures that epic dark, grim fantasy. It's horrible, it's gross, it's satisfying! 

The combat is simple but slick, enemies can be learned, so the experience rarely feels unfair, aside for one or two enemies who are truly aggravating. The bosses are well designed and unique. 

And finally, the lore, though complicated, is actually very digestible! It doesn't have that samey feel that writing in video games often conveys. Definitely playing this one through to the end, and will try and get my hands on a copy of the sequel.

149474970.review:
[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Blasphemous"[/h1]

Blasphemous es un metroidvania plataformero de scroll lateral cuya temática y estética, así como su combate meticuloso y relativamente exigente, lo asemejan lo suficiente a un Souls-like como para poder formar parte de dicha categoría.

El trabajo artístico es fabuloso, cada escenario es una belleza, cada jefe es visualmente único y cada track de la banda sonora aportan a la atmósfera de esta fantasía oscura inspirada en el Cristianismo.

Sin contar unas tres o cuatro veces que quedé atrapado en un hilo de ataques consecutivos de los cuales no pude escapar, en su mayoría Blasphemous es una experiencia justa y bien planteada, cuyo diseño de niveles es generalmente demasiado formulario pero completamente efectivo, destacando por cuán bien guía al jugador por el camino correcto y ofreciendo la cantidad suficiente de secretos como para compensar la atención al detalle.

Y aunque el ritmo de su combate denoten un evidente aire a Souls, ni los escenarios ni los jefes son particularmente exigentes hasta el último tercio. 

Quizá hubiera trabajado más en el backtracking, que es demasiado constante y monótono. Mientras que en otros Metroidvania adquirir una nueva habilidad representa una forma completamente distinta de manejarte por el entorno, en Blasphemous el juego empieza y termina prácticamente igual.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] Muy mejorable, pero fabuloso en algunos puntos clave.

149474229.review:
(My main file is on PlayStation, on which I've 100%'ed the game.)

If you like any Castlevania or Souls-style game, especially Hollow Knight, then you'll love Blasphemous.

Incredible art, unique animations and secrets everywhere, plenty of questlines and rewards for thoroughness, and a lot of great bosses without any real dip to the game's pace. The design team wanted a game that felt like it could've been Symphony of the Night, and I think they far surpassed that goal.

I wholly believe that Blasphemous is up there with Bastion, Dead Cells, and Hades as one of the greatest indie games ever made.

149290751.review:
The mechanics of the game are fun, and the boss fights are rewarding. But I can't honestly recommend this game due. 

In classic metroidvania form, the game requires quite a bit of backtracking/re-traversal of previously-visited areas. And there are many clues to let you know that you will need to revisit some places later on after you have acquired new items and abilities. But there are a *significant* number of item/places that are locked behind items and/or abilities which themselves are buried under a mountain of Dark Souls-level (in terms if the degree of indecipherability) fetch quests. It's just too much, and it's *extraordinarily* frustrating.

It's disappointing, since this game is *so* close to being amazing.

149277111.review:
Good art style, nice atmosphere, alright music.

Stiff and clunky controls, lack of mobility (both traversing and combat), confusing combat (how to approach enemies) and annoying enemy placement, vague storytelling.

I have little experience with Soulslikes or 2D platformers so I kept thinking "Maybe Im just bad at this and need to get used to it, be more strategic regarding enemies, patient in approach, etc.". No, this game has issues and people are most likely ignoring them because thats what people do with something they like, make excuses for its shortcomings.

I know its a different game, but I never had an issue accepting death or damage in Hades. Every time I failed a run I could see that I wasnt good enough in something. There was almost always a way I could escape damage, I just had to be better.
Here its the opposite. Almost every time I take damage I feel the game is cheating. I either cant move the way I want, the enemies are positioned in a way as to not let me handle them properly, trial and error gameplay and if you manage to put yourself in the wrong position you will get hurt a lot or even die. The times I did do well against the enemies I felt I was cheesing the game. Waiting near ledges to pick one off, waiting until other enemies go outside the screen.

Ive played games on hard difficulties before and hard games in other genres, so I can tell when the game is hard because I need to do more/better or when its designed to be vexing through artificial means. This one feels like the latter. A purity test through grinding gameplay.

4.5/10

149276891.review:
Blasphemous is a game that is so close, yet so far from greatness. For every great decision made in regards to atmosphere, there's a complete miss gameplay-wise.

Presentation? One of the greatest in gaming history. It's the main thing this game has going for it. The atmosphere is incredible. Switching to the Spanish dub is highly recommended. Sprites look great, stages are varied and beautiful too, animations are CRISP as hell.

The lore is very interesting but probably too sparse to fully dissect in a single playthrough. There are multiple endings, so replaying the game is encouraged.

Gameplay-wise? Very hit or miss. Combat feels punchy and impactful but basic at times, even after multiple upgrades. Platforming is not bad, just irregular. Some elements, like ladders, are very unreliable and sometimes lead to instant deaths by spikes. It's especially annoying when the game has time-based sections that are not exactly easy.

World design is GREAT. There are shortcuts and hidden passages everywhere. Going back to Albero through an elevator after 3 hours of struggle is awesome.

Bosses in general are decent. They're good enough, and very memorable visually. Some are annoying but nothing too bad.

Level design is good when traversing and exploring, but it has one fatal flaw: The worst aspect of Blasphemous in my opinion. Enemy placement. Some sections are very tolerable. Not easy, but manageable with some thought. Other sections took a page out of Dark Souls 2 and decided to throw around a f*ckton of enemies for no reason other than padding an already decently long game.

It's pretty good! It just feels like it needed a bit more thought put into combat to reach that extra quality. I still highly recommend it for the atmosphere alone.

7.5/10

149137712.review:
I have around 20 h in this game( 1 save file with 98% completion.)
I cannot recommend this game.It is...abnormaly frustrating.
-It is to to slow for a metroidvania, also it gets annoying having to always grab the edge of a platform then just being able to jump on it (as a side note, I find it funny that you can stand on the blood platforms but can't grab onto them)
-has a very simple combat system (which I know can be expanded but for 95% of the game you'll just be using the standard moveset ) which gets boring very quickly
-health and fevor upgrades are few and far between
- two of the most profitable quests require a guide to properly complete
-relics(I only have a complaint about one relics and its the one from the 3-headed creature,like, no casual player would have figured out how to progress their questline without looking up a guide and it is also one of,if not,the most essential relic when exploring cuz a lot of bone part,sword hearts and prayers require it)
-enemies either have infinite hyperarmour or none at all, some enemies  literaly cannot be ignored bc you MUST kill them to pregress further(looking at you humanoid statues in the ice area), the flying wizards can be knocked out of bound but they can still attack making the early game(when you don't have the holy blood throwable) very frustrating
-hit boxes are fine for the most part except for the nuns with the giant bell weapons
-OST's are solid ,nothing catchy but fitting
-early and mid game bosses are fun to fight but the late game ones are just frustrating(I am refering to the bell dude on the bridge ,the fire dude in the prison area,the last two bosses of the base game and the Gravetender lady where the bone collector is )
       -my main complaint about them is that it is near never clear when exactly the attack is going to happen due to the 
        animations being badly telegraphed and you will most certainly mistake one attack animation for another (take 
       a look at hollow knights attack animation and how very well telegraphed they are)
-fast travel locations are few and far between which wouldn't be a problem wasn't the games mobility so slugish
-prayer are either situational , underwelming, or down right busted like the one that creates two circling balls around you and the one that negates ALL DAMAGE for a couple seconds
-the fevor(mana) bar fills up far to slowly(it almost feels like they didnt want you to use it to begin with)
-no i-frames when after getting knocked down by an attack resulting in an easy stunlock
-having to waste a rosary slot just to be able to see the enemies health
-the jumping animation can feel incredibly slow for the fast humanoid bosses
-there are maybe one or two openings when you can safely heal up 
-healing animation is to slow
-i dislike the concept of having to sacrifice some of your currency AND heath to give yourself a chunk of fevor(which is pretty small if you want to use stronger prayers)
-the game is very unclear what you are supposed to do after entering the Mother of mothers
-sword hearts give mediocre buffs but give insane debuffs

These are all the things I can think of at the moment, wasn't really invested in the story but the visuals we stunning

Now,I don't want to make the game seem like it was made by the miracle(ha,get it) but ,taking into accountablilt everything  I have listed here, I really can't recommend this game to the faint hearted, more casual players 
for that I would rather recommend hollow knight

149067995.review:
Blasphemous is a challenging and addictive action-platformer that will keep you on your toes. For this reason I like it very much. But I love it for other reasons too… I love it because of its creative direction. For one, it’s mind-blowing how they’ve used religious imagery to create nightmarish monsters to slay. I applaud when a game builds its mythos so creatively from source material that you don’t see very often. With Blasphemous, the result is a universe that feels beautifully disturbing and unique.

But that’s not all: Blasphemous is full of Spanish (and more specifically Andalusian) flavor to a degree that makes me incredibly proud, as someone who has been living in this country for two decades. It’s not every day that you see a game translating so masterfully the soul of the studio’s region into a fantasy setting. From iconic architecture of Islamic origins to mystical visuals from Catholic rites, any small detail can be the seed for a dreadful creature or an awe-inducing region within the game’s Cvstodia.

Yes, Blasphemous is an incredibly fun game for those who can appreciate a good action-platformer with Metroidvania elements. But that’s not all: Blasphemous is a handcrafted love letter to the many beauties of a region with centuries of history that proudly intertwines heritage from many cultures.

My negative opinions:

Overall, a challenging game. You might rage at it though. It feels rewarding when you do well.

Score: B+

148885914.review: Este juego fue mi más profundo vicio este verano, lo conocí por un tiktok que decía que había un item honorífico a Berserk y a su autor Kentaro Miura. Pero dejando de lado todo eso, considero que este juego es grandioso, por muchísimos motivos, el primero sería su estilo gráfico, ese arte de bits me parece increíble, el como logra que los sprites, a pesar de ser bi-dimensionales aparenten lo contrario es algo que no se ve con todos los juegos que comparten su estilo, en segundo punto tenemos la historia y ambientación de mundo, ya que a mi lo que más me llama de un juego es su arte, pero a veces, la historia también forma parte de lo que me atrapa y me vuelve adicto a cierto título, daré un pequeño resumen luego, otro de los aspectos que destacaría del juego es su sistema de progresión, el mapa tiene un buen número de habitaciones que tienen como objetivo aumentar las estadísticas de tu arsenal (tu espada, barra de vida y demás), otro aspecto son los enemigos y jefes, la mayoría no tienen diseños genéricos, y muchos de ellos toman inspiración en antiguas leyendas de la cultura católica europea, la que me lleva a hablar de los escenarios, también fuertemente inspirados de ella algunos puentes, catedrales y habitaciones específicas están llenas de estas inspiraciones, la música, compuesta por Carlos Viola, le da vida a cada escenario que el protagonista pisa, en mi experiencia personal, no es tediosa, al contrario, se llegan a volver pegadizas y son bastante disfrutables, que le dan su sello al juego y suman puntos a la ambientación mística-medieval que rodea a este mundo ficticio, él último punto que quiero mencionar por sobre otros es su re-jugabilidad, dividida en : sus distintas dificultades y modos que permiten variar la experiencia de juego, y sus DLC, que para mi sorpresa, son totalmente gratuitos, no añaden mucho, pero si lo suficiente como para extender un par de horas su duración. Ahora pasando a la otra cara de la moneda, la de aspectos negativos, tengo solo 2 que mencionar, el primero sería la escasa o nula pista de que hacer en el juego, ya que la introducción es literal como cualquier juego de la saga souls, inicias te dan tu arma y a pelear contra un jefe, además, luego te permiten abrir tu inventario y ves que hay un montón de cosas que no te enseñan como funcionan, pero gracias a las guías de Youtube, puedes solucionar cualquier duda que tengas, y el otro, sería la complejidad de que hacer con algunos de los objetos que vas consiguiendo, porque algunos son de vital importancia para avanzar, y el juego no da ni la más mínima pista sobre como/donde usarlos, lo cual puede causar estancamientos al buscar donde usar X item que conseguiste en Y lugar. Ahora, esta historia se desarrolla en una basta y larga tierra llamada Custodia, la cual está sometida a los caprichos del Dios de ese mundo llamado "El milagro" que se manifiesta de variadas formas, en su mayoría negativas para los habitantes de la zona, encarnamos al último miembro de "La hermandad del lamento mudo" nuestro nombre es El penitente, y como cualquier otro habitante, sufrimos la manifestación del milagro con nuestra penitencia, la cual es el silencio (peculiar forma para hacer que el protagonista no hable), el propósito de este será cargar con las penitencias de todos los demás pueblerinos de Custodia, enfrentandose a mortales peligros y humillaciones con tal de conseguirlo, pero, lo hará? esa es una sorpresa que no quiero arruinarte, averigualo por ti mismo,  esta aventura vale la pena.

148879454.review:
I find myself just running past most basic mobs due to them needing to be parried over and over till they die. Because a lot of mobs carry impenetrable shields so you just have to wait till they strike to do damage. 

Add to the fact the levels love to swamp you with mobs on top of areas where you walk literally in swamps that slow you down. And spikes shoot from the ground, ceiling and sides. All while sewer pipes drip out poisonous sludge at a rapid fire rate that can take huge amounts of your health. I didn't mind aspects of the levels, but all jammed together it wasnt hard, just annoying.

Theres an area upward of the start where you must dodge lava cauldrons dropping. Some of the platforming is so tight that its impossible not to take damage at certain sections. Due to enemies instantly landing on your character as they pull themselves up off a ledge. I don't mind difficulty, but mandatory damage feels awful.

But then you finally reach the boss room and some vile, wicked creature strikes you back as an epic orchestra swells, heightening the frenzy about to unfold. You crush its skull and rip open its flesh, pooling its blood around you. Your character does something disturbing with its corpse and you think that was fun, lets go find another. And that sick cycle of annoyance through the level to the fun boss continues.

Game is brutal and punishing, but the metroidvania aspects of the gameplay kept me hooked and wanting more.

For every gripe I may have with this game, there is so much more to just gush about like the gorgeous spritework, the densely detailed environments, solid level design that still sloshes around in my skull like blood in your dude's helmet.

148842934.review:
Luego de 60 horas de juego y estar a solo 3 logros de platinarlo al 100% esta es mi reseña
Jugabilidad - 9.0/9.5 Una cagada total el 4to golpe de finalizacion de combo debido al tiempo de empleo
Lore - 10 En juego en si es una oda a la religion en todo su esplendor, si te gustan esos temas te gustara
Arte Panoramico - 10 Sinceramente cada paisaje es una joya visual, visualmente se aprecia el tintado digital meticuloso hecho con cariño y dedicacion
Dificultad del juego base - 6 Los jefes son demasiados sencillos, Existen 3 plegarias que te facilitan inmensamente las peleas contra los jefes tanto asi que puedes prescindir totalmente del uso de matracez biliares en sus peleas.
-Tiento a tus cabellos espinados, plegaria que te vuelve inmune al daño durante 6 segundos
-Zarabanda del refugio seguro, plegaria que invoca 2 orbes que giran al rededor de ti inflingiendo daño y protegiendote de proyectiles. Dicha plegaria es mi favorita nada mas por el hecho de que cada golpe que inflinges tu y los orbes a un enemigo lo detienen durante 0.2s. En conclusion, con ataques continuos puedes hacer izzi pizzi a Isidora, Sierpes e incluso al Hijo ultimo del milagro.
-Debla de las luces, Quieres deletear un jefe o hacerle 30% de daño de una sola plegaria al instante? esto es lo que buscas.
Duracion - 9 El juego dura lo suficiente para no fastidiarte ni tampoco dejarte con ganas de mas.
Exploracion y mapa - 10 Bastante extenso y variado, digno de un verdadero Metroidvania
Desafios - Sinceramente solo me tope con 2 cosas que creo fueron las mas tediosas de todo el juego.
La quest del caliz de los versos invertidos y los desafios de los espejos Strife & Ruin, en comparativa el caliz es de dificultad media y su recompensa muy alta en cambio los Strife & Ruin son tediosos solamente pero su recomenza al final de los 5 es la pobreza misma.
Dificultad DLC - 6 Sinceramente incluso sin usar plegarias las primeras 4 amanecidas te llevara 2 o 3 intentos a lo mucho, algunas incluso hasta en el primer intento podrias derrotarlas. El panorama de las amanecidas esta muy bueno pero la dificultad deja mucho que desear, Esperaba que Laudes (5ta amanecida) Tuviera una pelea en 2 o 3 fases asumiendo asi la posicion de jefe definitivo de todo Blasphemous pero....No.
Solo es una pelea en segmentos, cada cierta cantidad de daño cambian sus patrones de ataque un poco pero en esencia sigue a ras de lo sencillo.
A diferencia de Resident evil 7, Blasphemous es un juego que disfrutas al estarlo platinando y comenzar una nueva run ya que en cada nueva partida tienes la posibilidad de obtener de 8 a 20 trofeos.
Menciono a Resident evil 7 por que cada nueva partida del juego es un verdadero calvario que te obliga a pasar por lo mismo al menos durante 5 partidas nuevas para lograr obtener el platino.
En conclusion: Comprate Blasphemous y juegalo por cuenta propia, cuando le tomes cariño te daras cuenta de que todo lo que leiste en este post es lo mas justo a una reseña.

148619581.review: Blasphemous has taken me almost 4 years to finish because of my inconsistency with games that take me out of my comfort zone. This is also exactly the worst way to tackle games like it, causing me to restart solely because the idea of re-identifying my current place within the playthrough was too daunting. In one stretch, the game is a purposefully vague, gross, frustrating and ultimately satisfying soulslike platformer. You're really left to your own devices, exploring the areas that you determine most viable and annotating your map to make the lack of handholding bearable. I'll say that some spells and abilities feel quite niche but when you're able to apply them to the already punchy combat, it's exciting. Impressive grimdark visuals pulling from a Roman Catholic aesthetic that makes you feel feeble and bad.

148616097.review:
So far I am 20 hours into the game and was loving it, but when I got to the boss that is in the middle of a bridge, my love for this game ended.

That boss is very difficult to be in that area, if it was a final boss, I can say: "Okay, this is final boss!", but no.  I have spent some much time upgrading my status and abilities in order to defeat this boss, but with no luck.  I have completed all of the other areas, and not this boss stops my progress.  I think the developers were trying to mimic Dark Souls games, but forgot to keep the fight fare and balance with this boss.

Another thing that I do not like is when the game punishes you for dying; you loss a portion of your magic meter.  And when you re-spawn, you magic meter is depleted.  Making me not want to use it at all for any reason.

The developers decided to copy the stuff that people hated about the Souls games, and add them to this game, instead of copying the good stuff people loved about those games.

Anyway, I will continue to try to fight this middle boss, but I am not having fun with this game, which is the main point of playing games in first place.  Wish me luck!

148559817.review:
Nunca he escrito ni una sola reseña de Steam en español, pero me siento en la obligación de hacer una excepción con este juego, ya que se trata de una obra tan decididamente española que simplemente no me queda más remedio. Así que venga va una reviú pa' el blasfemias vamono.

Lo primero que hay que destacar de Blasphemous es que si eres de España, la sensación de familiaridad con la iconografía, la arquitectura y la temática general de Semana Santa presente a lo largo de todas las áreas del juego es brutal. Y bueno, ya si eres de Sevilla me imagino que dicha sensación se multiplica por mil, no?

Nunca jamás de los jamases juego con voces en español, pero al escuchar un poco el diálogo en inglés me quedó bastante claro que la experiencia definitiva tenía que ser, inevitablemente, con las voces en español. Y que grata sorpresa me llevé al escuchar el increíble trabajo de los dobladores españoles. Mi mandíbula se desplomó hasta el suelo cuando escuché al primer NPC con acento andaluz, verdaderamente lo nunca antes visto para mi.

Y en cuanto a lo que se refiere a gameplay,  hay que decir que es un juego muy bien diseñado. Por supuesto, como todo buen metroidvania, hay que leerlo todo y prestar atención a lo que dicen los personajes para no perderse después, pero en general la progresión es intuitiva y explorar todos los rincones del mapa resulta satisfactorio. Basicamente, nunca hay ningún objetivo extremadamente rebuscado que te obligue a buscar la solución en internet. Si es verdad que para sacar el final verdadero hay que seguir una serie de pasos bastante específicos que pueden ser  un poco más difíciles de deducir, pero al ser opcional no afecta a la experiencia de juego. 

El combate a pesar de no ser muy profundo cumple con creces y es generosamente complementado por el buen diseño de enemigos y jefes. He de decir también que me encantó la colaboración con Bloodstained, muy buenos desafíos de plataformas y encima con Miriam hablando en español!

Tremendo el juego, tremendo.

Very fun metroidvania! Not THE most difficult, or fast paced but REALLY good! A few constructive criticisms tho:
1) The last boss was very unticlimatic. Way easier than every other one, with 1 BS move to make it artificially hard.
2) Again on the last boss (and second to last) - it's very poorly designed/implemented. Any enemy that relies on staying out of the screen, or invulnerable while you have nothing to do but wait or dodge his BS is not fun. Por lo demás es un juego que merece la pena jugar si o si, que no os engañe el apartado pixel 2D, es envolvente, bonito y retador. Mi puntuación es un 9/10

148456124.review: Quite frankly this is long overdue; I love this game, it has a very souls like gritty atmosphere/lore, a setting that looks like it could serve as inspiration to a 13-14th century renaissance painting, all done in pixel art plat former, whats not to love. As a platformer the combat is reasonably paced, the execution animations are hot, and every expansion had me excited. If I had to be critical of this game it would be in the fact that I don't believe it has a high replayability, once you reach 100% it becomes more difficult to go back and get some of the achievements, especially the ones involving NPC deaths. the multiple endings and expansions kept me going back just to see what was new but I think after experiencing everything once I was quite content to leave it. which brings me to my other point, as nice as the game play is I find I valued the game more as an interactive art piece than a hack and slash adventure. This has been a treat and I look forward to the second game when I have the free time/budget for it.

I tried to like it, but it just wasn't fun.

The controls are clunky, most of the map is platforms and the jump move leaves no room for error. Attacking and dodging is sticky, and attack range is very short. Many pitfalls and insta-kills and the save points are too sparse so you have to start all over. The guilt mechanics just drains the fun even more, because if you made a careless error you'll have to backtrack through a punishing trail.

I get it, you want to make this a pixel-platformer version of dark souls, but it's just,,, artificially hard and not naturally hard...

A counter-example of how to do "hard" right is Celeste. Everything there was so polished that you had only yourself to blame for not succeeding. Blasphemous just makes you a cripple, and then laughs at you when you fall. I don't get it.

I got this game from humble bundle, and put off playing it for a long time because of the souls-like tag. I'm not the biggest fan of that genre, but I do enjoy metroidvanias. After finally playing it I would definitely recommend it to anyone thats a fan of metroidvania. I don't find much in this game to be very similar to souls other than corpse runs. Which you're not required to do, as theres other ways to retrieve your 'corpse', and you also don't lose currency, and if you die before retrieving your 'corpse' the previous one doesnt go away.

When you die you drop a 'guilt knot' which decreases your MP cap, and makes you receive less currency until you retrieve your guilt knot. Eventually you will find places you can pray for a currency fee to reclaim all guilt knots if you dont want to go retrieve them.

Souls-like also seems to be tied to difficult games, and I didn't find this game to be any harder than some other metroidvanias, combat is pretty straight forwards and most bosses are pretty straight forward with their moveset and mechanics. So if you're not into souls but into metroidvanias, I'd highly recommend giving the game a shot.

148306685.review:
One of the most fun Metroidvanias I've had the pleasure of playing in a good long while.

Some early platforming sections aside, Blasphemous really respects the player's time and doesn't wallow in cheap deaths. Small things like enemies can't knock you off platforms if you're not airborne, you can refill magic at a slight health/currency cost whenever, and more really sand off design edges where many other current developers are wallowing in bull***t to make you angry. If you're tired of playing games that are "Dark Souls-inspired" (read: a lot of bad difficulty balancing and mean-spirited level design that makes you not want to repeat the same souls run again and again), this is a breath of fresh air.

It's not without its minor issues (fast travel could be better, the way the updates was implemented is jumbled and confusing without Googling, etc) but all-in-all a game that only becomes more fun the further in you get. It's never particularly complicated or difficult at length (you rarely get stuck) and some people might want deeper combat, but the rich art and generous parry system means you're always seeing something new (gorgeous and/or upsetting to gaze upon) and moving at a steady clip. 

I'd recommend looking up a guide for Ending C since it's easy to miss, by the way.

148294282.review:
Forgive Me, Father, for I Have Selected the Wrong Tab

Ah, Blasphemous, the intriguing spiritual journey into realms of agony and ecstasy, where every chain, every spike, every pit of despair seamlessly blends into a delightful tableau of pain and pleasure. Quite the peculiar gaming experience, if I do say so myself.

As I dove headfirst into this pixelated penance, I couldn't help but marvel at the intricate detail of the leather outfits, the compelling use of chains, and the artful application of punishment so vividly displayed. The character's passionate cries of pain (or was it pleasure?) reverberated through my speakers, instilling a tangible connection to their plight.

Navigating through dark dungeons, I marveled at the impressive lengths these developers went to make the experience as immersive as possible. The masterfully executed whips, the constrictive outfits, and the methodically placed torture devices were almost too realistic. My hands shook (from excitement, surely?) as I carefully guided our masked protagonist through their tumultuous journey of salvation and suffering.

The detailed animations were simply stunning—how every wince, every shudder of pain was so vividly captured on screen. However, I did find it slightly odd when the characters began to engage in activities that seemed... somewhat inappropriate for a Steam game. The whipping scenes were incredibly realistic, and the anguish on the faces of the penitent was palpable.

As the torturous journey unfolded before my eyes, I became increasingly perplexed by the lack of actual gameplay. I mean, where were the boss fights? The power-ups? The platforming challenges that I'd heard so much about?

It was at this moment, dear reader, that a dawning realization clawed at my consciousness: My in-depth exploration into the dark, painful recesses of the Penitent One's journey was, in actuality, a very different type of exploration entirely.

In my fervor to experience the acclaimed Blasphemous, I had mistakenly indulged in a completely unrelated BSDM video, venturing into a realm of penance that Steam certainly does not endorse.

So, while I cannot in good faith provide a review of Blasphemous, the pixelated world of sorrow and salvation, I can affirmatively say that if you’re into a different type of interactive, stimulating experience, there are certainly videos available for you.

And as for Blasphemous... well, I’ve heard it’s a hell of a good time.

148184413.review:
Qué decir de este juego que no se haya dicho ya? Es arte. Desde su contenido religioso, simbólico y poético, me refiero a que cada NPC, jefe y enemigo sencillo tiene su simbolismo, hasta los significados y reflexiones filosóficas de cada uno. Por otro lado, su historia con esa oscuridad que propone el juego conjugada con los significados y la poética de sus personajes hace de esta obra, me atrevería a afirmar, una de las mejores, sino la mejor, del género. Es maravilloso.
 En cuanto al diseño es precioso, quizás se quede atrás en comparación con otros similares, sin embargo es perfecto enfocado al tipo de juego que pretende ser. Sobre los NPC y jefes tienen un diseño brutal, todo demasiado bien pensado y animado, sumado a los sonidos y voces y a la banda sonora -que por cierto se torna épica en los momentos precisos, llegando a emocionarte-, hace de este juego una obra audiovisual incomparable, sublime y disfrutable en cada momento.
 Por último, después de haber perdido 63 horas de mi vida jugando esta joya con el objetivo de entenderlo cada vez más y platinarlo al fin, confieso que fue un tiempo exquisito que pasé extasiado y sumamente entretenido, además, personalmente, me llevo mucho contenido filosófico, sobretodo en torno a los personajes de las quest, que en mi opinión van más allá que de meras conversaciones con Penitente. 
Así que te recomiendo a vos que estás leyendo, que lo compres y lo juegues si todavía no lo hiciste, vale cada centavo y, con suerte, te va a poner a reflexionar si lees los textos, por ejemplo los de los muertos o de Redento, un hombre lleno de culpa que confía en que el peregrinaje lo va a expiar de sus pecados, mi preferido. Dejo acá unas frases del peregrino para terminar de convencerte:
 
"¡Oh, pecados míos! ¿No es suficiente un largo camino lleno de reflexiones?
 ¿Qué hay de los callos en los pies, los calambres en las piernas, la sed, la frente abrasada por un sol que parece no ponerse nunca?
 ¿Y qué hay de las torturas de pensamiento cuando la culpa se nos clava una y otra vez en el corazón?
 ¿Qué más castigo queréis, oh pecados míos?"
 
 Muchos juegos tendrán historia, plot-twist si se quiere, pero una obra de este calibre diría que rara vez se encuentra.

148181782.review:
Beat this with like 75% completion in 11ish hours. A pretty solid game with amazing art and great music. There are a decent number of bugs I ran into, but almost none of them were serious (mostly graphical bugs and a couple funny stuff). 

The gameplay is serviceable and fun, but not really innovative (not that I minded, I love simple and classicish games). Wasn't the hugest fan of the physics but got used to em. The map became tedious to traverse after a while. Many enemies were hit sponges but as the game progressed this became much less of an issue. 

I don't usually like RPGs, so I was glad there wasn't some kind of traditional exp system in place, more of a classic style metroid game with some light level up elements. I found a lot of the leveling up stuff for upgrades to be extremely cost prohibitive. Like Dark Souls, the exp and money are the same thing. There were expensive keys, expensive interchangeable upgrades, expensive flask upgrades, etc. Basically to get 100% of everything it felt like it would take a lot of mindless grinding and I'm just not interested in that at all

There was no metroid-like required backtracking with upgrades to reach new areas. I didn't mind it, some people might not like that.

Lots of annoying instadeath pits, many of them offscreen so be sure to look down before jumping.

The combat was fun, but at times felt a bit stiff. That's probably something they wanted, more akin to dark souls. But the time you're locked into doing special attacks was too high, I found blindly slashing at stuff was the most effective way to win. Which is a shame, because I was hoping the upgrades would be more fun. The dodge sometimes went to the opposite direction of where I meant, which was incredibly annoying.

The upgrades you do get are usually pretty tame and boring. There's a ton of different upgrade types and it was all pretty confusing which one was which. For instance, when I picked up an item I was always confused if it was a basic collectible, an inventory item, a rosary upgrade choice, a sword core, a major latent upgrade etc. I managed to beat the game with only one latent upgrade to help me through a certain environment, there were more apparently but somehow I missed them. There's a system in place kinda like hollow knight where you pick some modifiers, and even a special move. But none of them made the game feel significantly different. The upgrades you get by levelling are also all extremly basic and cost prohibitive for no good reason.

I felt like the bosses and enemies were mostly a bit tough, but usually fair. A lot of people said this game was really hard but I didn't find it especially difficult, I struggled more on DKC2 which I recently played through.

I really enjoyed when I got pretty good at the game and totally destroyed the toughest boss quickly. Was very satisfying finally figuring out how to maximize the damage.

I didn't really understand the story, and all the dialogue was incomprehensible to me. Much like Dark Souls! haha. Anyways, I might look up a youtube video on it later or something, but I didn't feel the need to know the story to have fun with it.

There's definitely a bunch of things in this that are total bullshit. But all great platformers have at least some bullshit, so don't let it deter you from trying it

Anyways, I would say definitely give this is a shot if you think it might be interesting. It's pretty solid and fun, and the graphics/music are great too. But don't expect another Hollow Knight or something. I would probably get this on a sale or something tbh

I heard Blasphemous 2 was much better, so I'm excited to give that a shot sometime :)

148160987.review: I don't know when we started slapping "metroidvania" on every 2-d action platformer, but it needs to stop. This is not a metroidvania, it is a 2-d darksouls platformer. If there is no ability gating, it is automatically *not* a metroidvania. I even see fps, and 3rd person games with "metroidvania" slapped on, they aren't even 2-d let alone have no ability gating.  Metroidvanias have 4 key components. enjoyable, fun movement, a world that beckons you to explore, abilities needing to be discovered to explore and open the world up further a.k.a ability gating, and a story that mystifies you making your lust for exploration burn vigorously. some would argue good combat/ bosses are key too, and I agree, however, it is not as important as those four. Metroidvanias are like mini epics where you go on some great explorative adventure starting out weak with little movement/abilities, and become something awesome as you progress, whilst you learn about your localle, why you're there, who you are possibly, why the events are taking place in the game, how did you end up here. These are all questions the player should be asking, and as they recieve answers, those should lead them into more questions and leave them scratching their heads. All that said, I think this game so far meets all these requirements but ability gating. In conclusion, the game is not bad, however, it should not be considered a metroidvania. It is not like metroid nor castlevania, it is like darksouls.

148048620.review:
Complex and Grotesque.

I think the game is fun, has great metroidvania exploration and collectibles. Elevated by deeply engaging thematic content. 

Despite what an initial look (and the title) might suggest, I would say this is only partially about religion. Far more substantively I believe this is a game concerned with the way we conceptualize pain. Most specifically the virtue of pain, expressed here through the lens of holiness, but more widely applicable in what we find beneficial pain culturally. The idea that someone must be punished with pain or suffering for their wrongdoings, whether it would be best to relieve someone of their pain or if it would be more virtuous to let it continue.

Religion mostly occurs here to convey the idea of a standing dogma that idolizes pain. The language of religion here is partly exaggerated to convey an extreme reverence for pain. Partly though, it is indicative of the idea that religion is often the lens used to justify what pain is good pain and what pain is not. In that way, I think this game has a lot to say about religion. It would be, however, quite short sighted to limit this critique of pain being a means of virtue, when the same narratives are so prevalent in general cultural understandings.

I mean to say this game doesn't merely say "look at these antiquated religious zealots" and go "religion bad," the bigger ideas say that suffering is an ugly thing, and relegating the blind worship of suffering to being antiquated practice would only be a way to put off examination of our own ideas about pain and how we feel about the pain of others.

Pretty wild game though, this one is extremely deep. Great fun, with some real wicked art direction.

148035996.review:
I played this back when it came out and despite some very obnoxious problems, it's overall a very enjoyable experience, so much so that I consider it a gem even though it makes me want to rip my skin sometimes.
The good things are that its lore, while taking a lot of inspiration from how Dark Souls' worldbuilding works, is pretty original, and steeped in my own culture. It's a lot of fun seeing an artstyle that brings elements of Spanish, and specifically Andalusian concepts into a dark fantasy setting. The Spanish dub is out of this fucking world. The quests are as convoluted as in a Souls game, you'll have to look at a guide for some of them if you want the 100%, but they're very rewarding. The combat is good, simple in its mechanics but with a lot of depth between different playstyles, specifically with spells (Prayers).
Most of the issues I have with this game is that it doesn't know what it wants to be. It's absolutely not a metroidvania, while you have many branching paths, you don't unlock new areas based on new abilities, but only on story progression. The abilities are used only for unlocking secrets. Even though it's not a metroidvania, exploration is key to the game. This is why it pains me so much that there are so many instakill mechanics, specifically pitfalls and spikes. Having pitfalls kill you outright takes so much out of the exploration, at least until you get the item that makes you "immune" to them (which is required for some secrets). While traversing the map, I dropped to a zone that was DIRECTLY BELOW the area I was in, there was even a ladder leading down, but you either go down the ladder, or instantly die. Like Ninja Gaiden on the NES. Spikes are a little less frustrating, they just kill you and make you stay overly alert when you just want to go from point A to point B.
To end on a positive note, the game has received 3 updates in the form of DLC that have modified the base game a lot as well. First of all, the added and already mentioned Spanish dub. Then, lots of secondary content, like the Bloodstained crossover, the 8-bit arcade game, and obviously the new areas added by the DLC. Third, but most importantly, the new ending is amazing. It fits very well with the world, despite it being a lot more hopeful than what the other endings were. Unlocking it, as you may have guessed, is very convoluted, but the feeling of actually coming to a breakthrough and changing the story as you knew it has made my latest playthrough a lot more enjoyable.

All in all, this game is an indie gem, as a spaniard, I'm proud of it, and you should buy it. Then play 2, it fixes most of this one's issues and follows from the new ending.

147967114.review:
Graphics and Art Style: One of the standout features of "Blasphemous" is its stunning pixel art and dark, gothic aesthetic.

Story and Setting: The game's story is deeply rooted in religious themes, with players taking on the role of "The Penitent One," a silent protagonist on a quest to break a curse that has befallen the land of Cvstodia.

Gameplay: "Blasphemous" is known for its challenging gameplay, drawing inspiration from games like "Dark Souls."

Difficulty: This game is notorious for its high level of difficulty. Some players may find the steep learning curve and punishing combat frustrating, while others will relish the challenge. 

Sound and Music: The soundtrack and audio design in "Blasphemous" are hauntingly atmospheric and contribute significantly to the game's overall mood. 

Replayability: "Blasphemous" offers some replayability through its multiple endings and New Game+ mode. 

Conclusion: "Blasphemous" is a polarizing game. Its dark, atmospheric world and challenging gameplay are its strengths, but they may also be its weaknesses for some players. If you enjoy challenging action-platformers with a heavy dose of religious symbolism and a distinctive art style, "Blasphemous" is worth checking out.

147727710.review:
The Spanish Inquisition never looked better.

Not my first souls game, but it is my first metroidvania. Finished it after 18 hours with 87% of the content completed, got Ending B (blind playtrough).

The idea of using this old spanish catholic theme for game of this genre its just amazing, specially when the devs have no fear of showing gore or crude themes, it really is amazing. The atmosphere of the levels, the pixel art, the music, its all top notch.

The bosses are just a piece of amazing work one after the other, from the visual design, to the lore they imply and surprisingly... the mechanics, no boss is a copy of another, they all have different mechanics you need to pay attention to. Some are big enough to engulf the whole screen, others use the level/environment for an advantage, others summon minions to help em and others are just a normal sized character like you. They really feel like a piece of art.

The puzzles are varied and actual puzzles you need to figure out how to approach em, tho sometimes can be hard due to the lack of clues. For example, to open certain closed door you needed to use the lever of an elevator 5 times in a row and i literally have no idea from were that came from, i ended up looking at the wiki because there was no dialogue, hint, number on the walls, picture, anything that hints that.

Now the gameplay, i know nothing of metroidvania games and how they are supposed to be, so im gonna give my opinion on this from a souls perspective: the dashing sucks, simple as that.

The parry is good tho you can't use it on like half the bosses or enemies, which i understand since the game forces you to jump around, duck OR dash.... and thats the problem, the game itself tells you the dash has invulnerability frames and it does not feel like that at all. While i do understand that you can't spam it (one dash after another) and there's even dedicated items in the game to help you with that, the i-frames on the dash are either super tiny or they just don't work on some enemies. Plus the response from when you press the button to when it gets executed on the screen is long enough to go to the kitchen and make myself a cup of coffee... well, not that long, but after playing a souls game i think you can understand what i mean.

But oh well, those few cons are not even close to deprive you from enjoying and finishing the game, so give it a try.

I give it a solid 9/10, may the Miracle... keep you? guard you?... not turn you into an abomination? anyways, have a good one sinners.

147704458.review:
Had fun playing this through when I was out of commission for a few days.  

On the positive - 
The artwork here is absolutely gorgeous, and the bosses are equally interesting and fun.  I didn't know exactly what I was getting into when I first loaded it up, and quickly realized the game expects you to put some effort into beating it.  It's on the harder end of the spectrum, but the combat is very fun and rewarding.  The enemy variety is tremendous - there's always a new enemy to encounter and nothing gets stale.  The theme and presentation are consistent and immersive.

On the negative - 
I got a little frustrated towards the end-game where a couple sections took me more tries more than I'd have liked, and one of the game's main ways of making things more difficult is by making you complete longer and longer sections between save locations.  Towards the end I forgot where something was on the pretty sizable map and I kinda knew what I needed to do, but wasn't completely sure.  The game does very little to guide you or tell you where to go or what to do.  You're also probably not going to just stumble on to the "true" ending unless you look it up.

Overall - 
Games are meant to be fun.  This game is fun, and beautiful.  It's definitely worth a play.

147696959.review:
[b]The good:[/b]
This game is sick. Combat is fun and rewarding, art is is fantastic, and the overall vibe of the game is well crafted. All (or at least most) the enemies in this game are so cool looking that every time I get to a new area that's the thing I'm excited to see most. On top of that all the boss fights are fun, unique enough, and also look really cool. The game is definitely more on the difficult end of the spectrum, but not so difficult that its unbeatable by the average gamer, though you might die a lot. 

[b]The eh:[/b]
The story is told in the typical fromsoft fashion where you're reading item descriptions to piece together what's going on. This can be hit or miss for some people. I don't necessarily mind it, but I'm not always in the mood to go lore hunting, especially if I don't know that it'll be worth it. For this game I mostly skipped on it, and let some random youtuber tell me what happened. I do regret that however, because the story is pretty sick. For the sequel I'll definitely do this on my own. Outside of the main story, the game adds some side quests that have you meeting some interesting npcs that result in some pretty memorable interactions.

[b]The not so good:[/b]
The platforming is the weakest part of the game without a doubt. Its just not tight enough for what the game demands of you in some places. Specifically with regards to blind jumps and instant death spike pits placed throughout the game, the platforming can result in some pretty annoying deaths, resulting in you trudging all the way back from your last checkpoint only to try again. This leads into the other minor gripe I had which was the backtracking. Now I understand this comes with the genre, but I think due to the overall difficulty, backtracking becomes much more painful in this game. Between, having to traverse through some of the not so good platforming sections and pretty much unavoidable enemies in some locations, it can really mean that it might take almost as much time as it did the first time around to backtrack through an area to get to a new location or something. You'll be stronger and have more health for sure, but that doesn't mean much if you fall into a spike pit trying to jump onto a finicky ladder.

[b]In the end[/b] the game is absolutely worth playing despite its flaws.

[h3] I had fun with this game, but I just can't recommend it. [/h3]

Disclaimer: My playtime of 18 hours contain 1 aborted playthrough to about 65% and 1 full playthrough to 96% completion.

Good:
- Combat is ok, a couple hitbox issues here and there, but overall bearable (as the game is quite easy)
- Art is something special, probably one of the game's stronger aspects
- OST is ok, nothing catchy
- Moment to moment gameplay is overall fun, but...

Bad:
- Death pits
- Death pits right after screen transitions
- Enemies that knock you off ledges from off screen (or nearly off screen)
- Traversal is not really smooth, not clunky, but not Ori smooth let's say (I think that's due to the way the game doesn't register jump inputs for enough frames after going off a ledge, a common design in even old school platformers)
- Not a lot of fast travel spots, but a lot of shortcuts. Still, with death pits around, you can't really go fast and have to stay careful, which becomes a slog in the last 10-15% of the game.
- Metroidvania traversal powers locked behind convoluted "trade in" and "equip this to proceed" quests
- True ending locked behind convoluted quest where you have to go everywhere in the map to talk to NPCs at specific times.

The last 10-15% of the game left a sour taste in my mouth. It was just so painful going back through the map to find things, I just didn't really have fun at that point and abandoned trying to 100% my save because of it after the last boss.

147495384.review:
Hey you. Do you like Dark Souls? Do you like Hollow Knight? Do you like the old Castlevania games? Heck, even if you liked Super Metroid, then you'll like this. I could spend a million paragraphs critiquing it, but this is the concise way to sell it. Nasty "Souls-like" 2D Metroidvania, with more of a focus on exploring an open-ended world, instead of the more common Metroid style progression of using power-ups to open new areas. The concept and world-building centres around a Medieval Spanish Catholicism gone Cosmic Horror setting that's very vague but no less hugely atmospheric and interesting. 

The combat is weighty and heavily focused on timing and patterns and planning how to engage an enemy ahead of time, rather than say, the free form, weightless improvisation of something like Hollow Knight. The platforming action and level design panders to classic Nintendo shtick along the lines of Ghosts & Goblins, punishing albeit not as downright antisocial as its forebears. The boss fights are always a laugh, frantic and oppressive, challenging but never truly too much to overcome. The entire world is crammed with cryptic, arcane side quests to complete hidden objectives, I ended up having to use a guide for some parts, but your mileage may vary.

The whole package is fun. It's subtly silly, it's often frustrating and overwhelming and bewildering, but it's ultimately rewarding and really makes you feel like you've overcome a real challenge. Some nitpicks here and there, but this does too many things right to really hold anything against. Obvious recc for anyone who likes this kind of thing.

147422081.review:
Blasphemous is in every way I can think of that matters, a 2D souls-like.  Of course there are many games you could call similar to souls games, such as Hollow Knight, but that game didn't necessarily contain the spirit of a souls game. Many games take the functional part of those games, without also considering the narrative or artistic style that From Software has achieved during the making of the souls series.  This is what blasphemous does.  Game mechanics wise, it's a competent, smooth 2D metroidvania with sparse checkpoints, perilous platforming and out of this world artistic  style.  But what it incorporates that truly make this game an achievement, is a comprehensive and thought provoking narrative about blind faith.  This pairs up with the art style really nicely to create a brute, unforgiving world where your goal is to do something of meaning.  Whatever ending you choose, in this game, what really matters is the fact that you did it and reached the end.  The confusing story makes it difficult to understand if you had any impact in the world, but that's irrelevant.  You gain purpose because you went through the game.  That I think i the heart of souls narratives, and this game does it better than any 2D metroidvania I've seen (yes, including Hollow Knight).  However, the game play left too much to be desired. It didn't pair up as well as other metroidvanias do with their story.  There is of course a narrative reason for everything that you have at your disposal, but what didn't pair up well is a really important part of these type of games: character growth.  This game has  a leveling system, but it didn't feel as satisfying to actually get to the end in 2 ways:

1. A game like Hollow Knight makes you feel much more powerful if you find specific items in the game, since it almost always means an upgrade.  But specifically, it constantly mixes gameplay styles you can choose from.  Blasphemous has only 1 weapon, and that's it. It has lots of spells, but it takes too long to use one of them, and their effects are not all that different at the end.

2. Typical souls games made by From Software pair up the upgrade system with character growth. A great example of this is Elden Ring, where you feel a bigger sense of achievement because you get materials needed to perform an upgrade.

Of course, Blasphemous is like neither of these games.  It's a 15-20ish hour game which doesn't need such complicated mechanics. The problem is though, that those mechanics are essentially just wishes that were left by me when I finished the game.  I wanted more.  But Blasphemous didn't show that much gameplay. It being short was not a problem, mind you, but the big problem is that the game could have become much braver when it came to the part of conceptually designing gameplay mechanics.  It kind of is already, there are for example many death pits in this game which would confuse and frustrate players, but they were done carefully such as to never be as annoying as platforming sections in Castlevania games.  The real problem for me though, was that it didn't do enough of these things: The gameplay lacked the variety and beautiful color to truly represent the narrative of this game.  Therefore, it's easier for you to struggle understanding why this  this game is entertaining you. I did, but that's only because I came into this game knowing it was going to be a 2d souls game. 


In conclusion, this game is a beautiful, well built game which will likely be very fun for most that play.  However it's arcane narrative may be lost to some players not because they hadn't tried to get the feel of it, but due to the game not having gameplay complex enough to warrant people reading, or caring enough to explore it more.  The thing that truly sets this game apart though is that it successfully reinvents in my opinion the most important aspect of a souls game (narrative-visual-gameplay loop) into a 2D metroidvania. So overall, it was a really great time for me.

8.5/10

147341839.review:
tldr; if you like old school fun games like Contra, you will love this game.

OK, this game is a GEM.
it is legitimately fun.
It starts off feeling really easy. Almost too easy. but man oh man does the difficulty level get hard fast. It takes skill, timing, strategy, and a little luck sometimes. The game play and controls are very smooth and responsive especially once you understand the controls.

One thing to note. The default keybindings (mouse & keyboard) are the absolutely worse I have ever seen in a game. I can't think of a dumber way to set the default control scheme. Why the Devs chose this is beyond me. The good thing is you can remap all the controls in options. There are lots of reddi post, steam threads, and other sites with tons of ppl asking for help in re-mapping the keybindings. (seriously the Devs have the worse intuition in assigning keybindings/controls). 
In order to get to the options menu, you have to open the map first and press "O". I never would have guessed this, and why the Devs didn't just go with the "press Esc key" to get to the main menu is ridiculous. 

ok, so end of negative rant about keybindings. Once I changed all the keybindings my game play is seamless and fun. 
The story is very dark, and I hope the makers of this game can sell the movie or TV rights, because this IP would make a fantastic movie/ series. The voice acting is top notch, and the writing is sooo good. If you love the darker elements of someone like Clive Barker (Hellraiser, Lord of Illusion, Book of Blood, nightbreed etc.)  you will love this story setting. 

For such a simple looking game it is really a pleasant find. I bought it on a whim and do not regret my purchase.

edit: Just to add, if this game came out in the late 90s early 2000s it would be on everyone's list as one of the best games of all time.

147335742.review:
I feel sorry to say this, but I do not recommend this game. I had high hopes for the game, especially considering the themes it was going to tackle: religion piety, dedication, mystery, striving for greatness. But after spending 15 hours of play on this game, I just could not bring myself to finish it.
I'll start off with the good - graphics look amazing, and each boss is an artwork deserving of presentation in a church or a monastery as an icon. The map is rich and full of secrets. The enemy variety is enough for its purposes.
That leads to my criticisms: the gameplay is way too simple. Yes, you can unlock many different attacks, spells, upgrades, but for the most part the game consists of Dodge, Spam attack, Dodge, Spam attack, sometimes use Spell etc.. And to be honest, that might've been enough for a recommendation, but the story (or lack there of) is what snuffed out my interest completely.
I was hoping some sort of integration of game mechanics and story themes, where the symbolism, the metaphor is intertwined with the gameplay, but the gameplay and the story seemed to begrudgingly shake hands when absolutely required. The only mechanic I can think of that had any sort of symbolism behind it was 'cutting' yourself to open a locked gate, and then there was no use for it. (I am aware that you can cut yourself to fill your Mana/Penance, but you can easily ignore that).
Honestly, at that point in the game I felt like the developers (who have done a great job of making this game) made a good, but a bit standard, metroidvania, and then chose the setting of near-catholic world, where sin is manifested in real world. And even then, just as so many other storytellers before, came up with the idea of making the church/gods/saints the bad guys/corrupt.

TLDR: a good, if not standard, metroidvania with a fine gameplay loop, but the story-mechanic dissonance kills all interest
