147306418.review:
When it comes to the atmosphere and the general aesthetic Blasphemous is near perfection. The grimy and visceral visions of grimdark catholicism is, beyond the cyclopean richness of Warhammer 40k, pretty much an underused setting. Everywhere we go we are bombarded by gnarled roots and roses, twisted gothic architecture with an overdose of skulls, death, spikes, and holy symbols. On top of that we have a gameplay revolving around the meticulous collection of various anatomical features of dead geezers and crones, prayer beads and suffering to increase our everlasting torment.  

The story takes place in Cvstodia, the epitome of Catholicism gone haywire where we play as the last of a fraternal fellowship of coneheaded penitents sworn to silence. On our quest to topple the chosen one of the miracles we encounter fellow blasphemers, saints, sufferers and dogs. Honestly this game reeks of atmosphere and I guess the artwork and setting is somewhat of an acquired taste. If you find blood, gore and weird pseudo christian symbolism a bit too much, you might want to pick another game.. 

At íts core Blasphemous is a classic Metroidvania, albeit a rather cryptic one. The nonlinearity of the maps are spot on and to traverse the twisted landscapes we need to gather relics to alleviate our mortal forms limitations. Sometimes I found this to be a bit too cryptic, almost to a fault. However the gameplay in large is hugely satisfying and combined with the lovely worldbuilding I would say that this is a fantastic game! The boss fights are a mixed bag, I loved some of them, others were, well, way too harsh or way blander than expected.. All in all the gameplay is a slightly worse Hollow Knight, take it or leave it..   

In the end I highly recommend Blasphemous to anyone into great Metroidvanias. This is an instant classic and I really love when a game dares to not include an obvious double jump in the list of potential upgrades.. Enjoy it for the handcrafted images if nothing else, I never thought i'd be this intrigued by reinvented Catholic liturgy.

I wouldn't say its for everyone, you need to have that drive to fight through adversity, although the payoff knowing you persevered is what made me keep coming back

Un Metroidvania/Plataformas (tal vez demasiado de lo segundo) con un planteamiento distinto, mundo semi-abierto en 2d y misiones secundarias. Incluye también algunos elementos de Rpg y un sistema de Checkpoints y "Experiencia" tipo Souls.  El sistema de combate es completo, el mapa en todo momento se siente libre, el bestiario y el equipo son extensos y hay secretos a lo largo y ancho del mapa. Artística y Musicalmente es sobresaliente e incluso está traducido y doblado al Inglés y Español.
Como negativo resaltaría el aspecto jugable, algunos bugs muy puntuales que te obligan a reiniciar o, (en un título que requiere en ocasiones buen "timing") los controles te abandonan, Penitente está golpeando en la dirección contraria o las plataformas simplemente te dejan pasar de largo. Aún con estos contratiempo, sigue siendo un juego accesible y totalmente disfrutable,
Blasphemous es un juego que toma prestadas muchas cosas de manera inteligente y las fusiona dentro de un envase único y bien cuidado. Muy recomendable para la gente con gusto por lo retro o con un fin de semana libre (o tal vez más si terminas atrapado en Cvstodia).

146903394.review:
This is honestly a tough review. There's no denying I was addicted to this game during my first play through. I couldn't put the controller down as I wanted to continue to progress through this 2D metroidvania. Most of the game seemed pretty linear in terms of the progression. The story was compelling and, as the protagonist, you wanted to learn more about this world you were immersed in. The combat is simple to pick up and mobs are not egregious. Save locations are placed fairly distant from one another, giving a fair challenge. Variety in buffs allow some semblance of choice within the game as well. 
The longer I played however, was when the flaws started to peak out. This became especially apparent with NG+.

From a completionist stand point, there are achievements that are completely miss-able, which includes the 100% achievement. There are absolutely no indication within the dialogue of NPCs to guide players for certain key items (such as the item for double jump or the wall climbing vine) that halt progression (if I am incorrect with this, I accept the possibility that I may just be an idiot). There were instances where mini bosses, who are in there own rooms, would bug out after parrying (this can be extremely frustrating having to backtrack back to the boss and any semblance of progress is loss. Not to mention these mini bosses can be tough, forcing you to replay the instance several times over). DO NOT GET ME STARTED ON SOME OF THE PARRYING. Call me a bad gamer but I don't know what estranged Spanish saint I have to pray to but Christ theirs some bosses that are absolutely broken. It all just feels some what...clunky? 

Long story short: Not as good as Hollow Knight. Fun game, SHITTY to complete.

146887387.review:
Blapshemous is a great game plagued by a few poor design decisions. The moment to moment gameplay feels great, navigating the world, uncovering its secrets, and fighting bosses is intensely satisfying, with the religious imagery of Spanish Roman Catholicism tying it together. 

A couple poor design decisions mar the experience. There's a fair amount of platforming in the game, all of which features spikes and endless pits that insta-kill the player. This results in a death screen, load screen, and then walking back to the platforming section to try again. This very easily could have been replaced with a quick respawn and some health lost. This is especially apparent in one of the DLC quests with Castlevania crossovers. Being a veteran platformer player, I enjoyed these lengthy speedrun challenges, but they definitely felt out of place. 

The second issue is more deep-seated. Several points in the game lock you out of content and bosses. In order to see everything Blasphemous has to offer, you must do atleast 2 playthroughs. Normally, this would be no issue, but the length of Blasphemous and the nature of its unlockables left me with a sour taste upon seeing this. There are a few other quests that have hidden triggers for progression, which will lock you out of happy endings and Achievements if you are interested in that. 

I didn't have it in me to do a second playthrough of Blasphemous, but for those up for it, it offers plenty of new content, story, secrets, and unlockables. The continued support in the form of small DLC packages helped make Blasphemous into a more complete experience.

146696564.review:
[h1]Blasphemously good[/h1]
Awesome game, love the theme, the concept the whole thing but it is hard, like Sisyphos hard.
As an old Metroidvania player since the dark ages, I feel familiar and a bit comfortable until I realize this is a game that touches the OG Castlevania level of difficulty. After exploring and poking and smacking around, getting tons of very holy items and equipping myself with everything extremely holy and sacrosanct until I felt extremely saintly with a sword, I managed to delve further into the sins of the inhabitants and remove that said sin with the help of mea culpa and a little bit of force. The creativity of this game and the obvious catholic inspiration is so much fun to explore, everything from visuals to sound and music to the lore.

However, it is a very difficult game, that does get a little bit easier down the road when you get used to it, explore and find power-ups and equip yourself with some of the items you'll find. Still hard despite that, and you better get good with the controllers and enroll in a plat-former boot-camp to improve your reaction time. 

In short, it's a game made by sadists, for masochists.

[h3]Some Good Points[/h3]

[b]Music[/b] - Love it, beautiful iberian themed music, you can feel the Inquisition around the corner.
[b]Sound[/b] - I actually find it well put together - it feels right most of the SFX effects and work with the overall theme.
[b]2D graphic design[/b] - Absolutely fantastic I loved every inch of the game world's graphical design and all the characters as well!
[b]Content[/b] - absolutely enough for the price-tag, for sure. Some of it is good, some is better and some of it should've been thrown into a dumpster fire while in concept stage of their design ... imho (see below)
[b]Difficulty[/b] - It is very difficult and very much so in the beginning until you gradually learn how to play the game and avoid some dangers, handle the controls and how to deal with some enemies. I can say for sure I'm not the best platformer player, and I struggle with some bosses so I won't be able to beat some of them without flasks, for now. I don't know how many times I've died (least hundreds of times for sure) in the game and how many times I simply quit the game in the mid of it and had to do something positive to counterbalance the frustration.
[b]Creativity[/b] - I'd say it is exceptional, it is so fun to take it all in visually and audio-visually the whole game, the story is absurd as well but the fun part is that people really were nuts back then when it came to the whole sin-concept going into overdrive in Catholicism (especially).

[h3]Some Less Good Points[/h3]

[b]Quest Design[/b] - Really convoluted and obscure. I ending up checking a guide because I got stuck and it took too much time to keep running around and around not understanding the triggers of some of the quests, and yes I was right they were really convoluted.

[b]Glitches & Bugs[/b] - There are some moments albeit very rare the player char is stuck for some reason or can't dodge (end-game areas), thought my controller was bad but no it was an in-game glitch. There are also icons not displaying properly in the map, particularly the blood fountain in the second last area.

[b]Genre Content[/b] The Strife & Ruin content is something I'm not happy about since it is a type of a genre that I don't like playing, it wasn't what i wanted when I bought the game but it isn't game breaking to skip it, however it annoys the hell out of me since it locks me out from getting a full completion of the game. If I want to elevate my stress levels and enjoy masochism then I work double-shift while being screamed at, then play Meatboy while blindfolded and have my bare feet pressed on sharp glass shards while playing a recording with someone hating you non-stop on 150% volume after work, and no food or water. 
Not sit through another 2-3 hours TRYING to get the two last pieces by clearing the death-trap courses within given time. I hope it isn't in the sequel, seriously I pray to the Miracle it isn't, otherwise I'll skip buying it.

= = = = = =

[h2]Summary[/h2]

Buy it without a doubt, but be mentally prepared, have a sturdy controller of at least Nokia quality and an anger-management tool ready beside you and be ready to accept you'll have to skip content so you don't lose sanity.

Game made by the Inquisition on steroids - I give this game 38 out of 38 Cherubs 
(except Strife & Ruin, it can go F itself [b]"%&"#&/#&!![/b])

146633066.review:
[h1] Great combat system, not a great metroidvania[/h1]
Blasphemous is a game I got enough out of I'd feel bad giving a thumbs down for, but I'd give a thumbs in the middle if I could.

I really enjoyed the games combat, especially the parry system made dodging and timings for boss fights and enemies fun. I typically find enemies in games more annoying than fun, so the fact that Blasphemous made me enjoy fighting and learning them is a huge plus. (Though some enemies were really annoying to fight)
There were 3 bosses I really liked, 2 I thought were good, and then the rest were kinda forgettable/mid (Final boss kinda sucks). This was the highlight of the game, though even with the bosses I thought were really good I felt like I was put into situations I just couldn't dodge. But for the most part I really liked the difficulty.

I really wasn't a fan of the exploration of the game. I went 15 hours not finding a single ability, just waiting to find the one ability that clearly every single path was locked behind, just for it to be locked behind some weird convoluted quest I had to be told how to do AFTER I already beat the game. Making the majority of the game just feel like I was just mapping out dead ends with no real reward the entire game. Because I was locked out of most of the map until after finishing the game and had to look up every single ability, everything just felt like some clean up fetch quest that just took all the fun out of the metroidvania exploration for me, that eventually I just gave up trying to find most of the stuff because it was basically meaningless at that point. The map is also really big and most areas just felt kinda pointless to fight your way through because bosses were so spread out and you rarely find something useful.

Unlike most metroidvania's the abilities are also not anything the player can actually use like a movement ability or something, they just spawn platforms and walls, or just immunity to some hazard so you can go through an area. Basically just keys to a door with lack of player interaction. Which makes it especially confusing as to why you can only have 3 equipped at a time? Just made it so when I saw something I could interact with I had to go into the menu and change what I was wearing for that room to interact with it. 

Spikes and pits killing you instantly (which you usually fall into because you just walked into a room or they're off screen) are extremely annoying and made exploration especially tedious at some points. 

Fast travel in the game is very tedious with how spread out it is. You do get an upgrade for this hidden behind some random donation that doesn't tell you what it does or how much it takes, or even how much you've put in. This is where the most important upgrades in the game are hidden behind. 

There are many side quests you can get locked out of if you don't follow the very strict requirements and look up exactly what to do before ever progressing which can lock you out of certain upgrades which is really lame. 

There's also an INSANE amount of money grinding if you want to get all the upgrades, because stuff costs way too much for how much money you get by just playing casually.

There are 5 dedicated platforming segments and they are horrendously awful. They're speed challenges with no control over how fast you can go due to just waiting for really slow cycles to carry you over to the next platform. On top of which the last couple are really long, and an attempt is over in an instant because falling into spikes 1 shots you.

I encountered a bunch of small little bugs here and there, mostly graphical, a couple that just made me fall through the ground and died when I shouldn't have, or where I lost horizontal control of my character, or just fell through a platform I clearly landed on. Only really effected game-play during the already awful platform sections. 

Though it clearly had a lot of work into it, which I appreciate, I gave up pretty quickly trying to understand the story, there was just wayyy too much reading that's in old English, that was too difficult for me to really decipher, and would have just taken too much time away from actually playing the game. I also don't like this kind of setting, but that's just me. This is by no means a bad thing, I know some people love super cryptic hard to understand story; I do to some extent but not on this level. 

The Art and Music are both incredible, clearly a lot of work was put into the atmosphere of this game.

Apparently the best parts of the game are locked behind a new game plus cycle but I seriously don't feel like replaying the whole game.

Overall: the systems and progression in the game were just way too confusing and hidden, there were some fun bosses and enemies. Looking forward to how the next game improves.

146614118.review:
[h1]Sorrowful be the heart, Penitent One.[/h1]
Blasphemous. The game that I bought and immediately forgot about a thousand years ago. The game that I didn't expect much from upon my return, but ended up having a whole lot of fun. 

I never considered myself a hardcore fan of the Metroidvania genre: for various reasons, I couldn't beat Hollow Knight and Ori, and the more "classic" games like Bloodstained didn't click with me at all. However, this game sucked me in literally an hour after starting, and didn't let go until the very (true) ending.

🟢 [b]Well-Paced Exploration[/b]
Amazingly smooth difficulty curve combined with the non-linearity of the world and abundance of secrets, from items to entire locations, provides an extremely enjoyable gaming experience. 

Character stat progression is absent in the game at all, and currency is spent on rare weapon upgrades and potions. In the case of potions, there is a permanent loss of one for each upgrade. Cool decision, design-wise. 

The meta elements here are quite interesting, as the most useful upgrade the player receives is obtained through donating currency at a local church, which, upon reaching a certain threshold, grants the most convenient fast travel in the game. Although initially, it may seem that these donations are pure flavor.

🟢 [b]Awesome Combat[/b]
The combat system is simple and quite intuitive. In most cases, opponents — regular mobs and bosses alike — are perfectly readable. Their animations are clear and well-optimized, with precise timing that allows the player to parry or dodge in time. 

I would also like to mention the boss fights. In the worst cases, they are... pretty standard. In the best cases, they are astonishing. I swear, I will remember Sierpes and Crisanta for a long time. Especially the latter’s second phase which is mostly based on perfect parrying.

🟢 [b]Lore & Aesthetics[/b]
The reason for my return to Blasphemous was its absolutely unique style, which is emphasized by an intricate and complex story with Spanish cultural and religious references. The imagery is so cool that it stays in my mind long after I close the game. And it will stay, I’m certain of it.

All of this is conveyed through pixel art. As a simple human being, I love pixel art. I draw pixel art. I am inspired by it. Here it is of high quality only. Some backgrounds are begging to be used as wallpapers. And certain music tracks will definitely make it into my playlist and serve as background music for role-playing games.

🟡 [b]Well, Platforming[/b]
To me, the only problem this game has. And it is highly subjective. The only thing to ever compete with the bosses is… iron spikes. Carefully placed literally everywhere, they are ready to annihilate you the moment your reflexes go numb for a single second. And considering how much jumping this game offers… 

However, suffering is the way. The Souls series told us.

An absolutely stellar game with an immersive design, story, and a banger of a soundtrack. You could call it a metroidvania Darks Souls, but I don't think it deserves to be labeled as such. The backdrop of the Spanish Inquisition (which no one ever expects!!!) lends it's itself perfectly to the bloody and grim setting of the world of Cvstodia. The platforming and combat feel nice and responsive, and there is a decent variety of enemies, speaking of - their design and that of the bosses are absolutely sick! 
As a negative, I would point to the cryptic questlines of most of the characters (which is definitely borrowed from DS). You would most likely miss or botch a lot of them on your first playthrough. The map navigation is kinda clunky....and whoever designed the lamp "double jump" and the jumping from ladder to ladder can go straight under the Penitent One's boot. They are one of the worst platforming mechanics I've encountered in a platformer. Thankfully they are in optional areas, so you don't have to deal with them if don't feel like it.

I started the game thinking that I might not like it and not go to the end, and then I saw that I sat down 3 times in a row and finished the game. Wow, what an interesting and good game.

The story of the game was very mysterious and interesting and pulled me to the end of the game to unravel the mysteries, the art design and pixel art graphics are really well done, the characters and modeling may not be to everyone's taste, But I loved them, the music and voice acting fits the world and atmosphere of the game well and is enjoyable.

As for the gameplay, the creators have done well and made the movements and animations very good. For me, who had little experience in this genre of games, the game had a fairly balanced degree of difficulty, which, of course, became easier by upgrading and finding useful items, and I did not see any annoying problems in this regard.

Overall Blasphemus is a worthy game in this genre and I suggest you give it a try.

Score 9/10

146152092.review:
Blasphemous is a solid action metroidvania style game with an intriguing story, extensive lore, brutal combat and full of challenging moments both in it's exploration, combat and boss encounters. Though the game felt frustrating at the start of it all, once you get to learn to understand the mechanics and the importance of backtracking, you will be well on your way to being the ultimate Penitent One. 

[h2] The Story & World [/h2]

The story was quite solid in it's execution, going for a more dark souls like way of telling the story rather than telling you exactly what happens. In a way, it kept me well engaged. Many metroidvania games exceed at creating such unique worlds and Blasphemous doesn't disappoint in this regard, being heavily inspired by Spanish Religion, you will be going through many churches that all feel unique, in addition to snowy mountain plains, desolate hellish undergrounds, a toxic sewerage system or a ghastly Library. This is all accompanied by an amazing OST to represent the world/boss. Connected level design is also another positive thing about these types of games, providing ease of access to the player as a reward to prevent tedious linear backtracking. 

[h2] Gameplay & Progression [/h2]

How does the gamplay hold up? well as I mentioned before, it is truly a challenging game, every enemy you encounter after the Holy Line is unique with it's own attack patterns and behaviour with a total of 37 unique encounters (not including the bosses). Some enemies are stronger variants of each other (such as Acolytes) but all in all are unique to the area you are fighting them in. You will die a lot if you do not learn about the encounter or study the attack patterns of the enemies. By learning about what each enemy does within the encounter, you will have a better chance at succeeding and dying less. That being said, there is going to be a time where certain rooms filled with certain enemies can frustrate you and perseverance is the only answer.

The Penitent One has a decent array of movesets with his sword the Mea Culpa from a uppercut slash, a slow but powerful ground twirl, a plunge attack, a charged attack, ranged blood projectiles and a powerful dash lunge which can setup for perfect executions which are all satisfying to pull off. Along with upgrading your moveset, you can upgrade your healing items (as in the amount you can obtain/amount you can heal). Parrying and Dashing are your defence mechanics but iframes are not that frequent especially in boss fights, relying on reading the patterns of the boss you are fighting. All the bosses are unique to fight and range from powerful warriors to abominations. 

Progressing the game in order to become more powerful is tied to the world itself and exploring it deeply for secrets. You can obtain tears of atonement which is currency earned through killing mobs/bosses and progressing quest lines. By unlocking relics, they can help open new paths to explore and further expand your arsenal, such as and is not limited too: health upgrades, fervour upgrades, rosary knots/beads to give buffs/defences for certain scenarios, Hearts for your sword which will provide a huge buff along with a debuff, prayers and consume fervour to unleash powerful buffs, defences or attacks, collecting bones that unlock a new boss and cosmetic and finally finding Children of Moonlight to track down. 

[h2] Replayability [/h2]

After I was able to 100% my New Game file, the only thing left to do was play True Torment (NG+) which resets all of your progress while retaining most of the stuff you found already in that file. In NG+ as expected, you will fight enemies that are stronger and deal more damage but in return you earn more tears to make the grind less tedious and elongated. In addition you get 3 traits to choose from. Red turns the game into an old school side platformer where instead of a health bar, you get health orbs, which can help with annoying boss fights/traps/enemies. The Blue one weakens your sword attacks by half but allow your fervour to regenerate passively rather than having to earn it through attacks only. Finally the black one turns the game into dark souls in a sense where if you die, you lose all of your currency, cant use prayers and have to collect the guilt where you died and your flasks no longer heal health but fervour, making for a more punishing playthough but a good challenge nonetheless. by beating the game with each trait, you will unlock a new bead/skin. 

In addition to NG+, there is new content to play, such as fighting 4 skeletal bosses each with a unique weapon that has a unique attack pattern all to progress to a final boss that uses all 4, testing your skills and knowledge on the bosses you fought prior. A new ending is also unlocked where you have to explore the new areas to find it, as well as paying attention to the NPCs you encounter. Thee there is content is one I personally dislike as they are platforming challenges and that is the Strife and Ruin which was a collaboration with the Bloodstained series protagonist Miriam, as I found it to show a lot of the frustrating parts of the platforming in this game when presented as a challenge but thankfully that is just optional and you get a decent prayer as a reward so up to you.

Once you are done exploring all of the base game, you can challenge the bosses again in a progressive style known as Sacred Sorrows which will rank you based on many things and serves as a challenge.

Overall, I enjoyed my time with Blasphemous, so much to the point I wanted to 100% this games achievements and I'm glad I did, It provides a satisfying gameplay loop, allowing the player to discover a unique world where they are rewarded for paying attention to the little details and explore every nook and cranny to further progress the penitent one to become stronger than ever. A vast array of beads, prayers and hearts allow for extensive customisation and variety, all wrapped together with a story that is mysterious but extensive. Awelcome addition to action metroidvania games.

146102473.review:
I thoroughly enjoy this game for its exceptional soundtracks, captivating art style, engaging combat mechanics, intriguing story, attention to small details, extensive exploration, and diverse array of items. However, it's important to note some aspects that might not appeal to everyone, as well as my own experiences and what I've heard from others.

Hack and Slash: This game leans towards the hack-and-slash genre, which might not be everyone's cup of tea. If you're not a fan of this style of gameplay, it might not be the best fit for you.

Abundance of Items: The game boasts a vast inventory of items, which can sometimes lead to the need for external resources or guides to understand their full potential and usage.

Early Game Challenges: In the initial stages, the game can be a bit demanding as you work to accumulate currency, explore, and avoid perishing.

Confusing Elements: At times, the game's intricacies and plot can become a bit perplexing, potentially requiring extra attention to fully grasp.

Complex Lore: The game's lore can be intricate, and not everyone may delve into it deeply. Some players might prefer a more straightforward narrative.

Multiple Endings: There are reportedly three different endings in the game, which might not appeal to those who prefer to move on to new experiences once they've completed a game.

Despite these considerations, I personally found these aspects to be engaging rather than off-putting. The hack-and-slash gameplay, adorned with visually stunning gore effects, was right up my alley. The music resonated with me, and the pixel art was truly captivating.

If you share my passion for 2D games, adventurous exploration, metroidvania mechanics, diverse item combinations, and varied combat styles, then I highly recommend giving this game a shot. It's well worth the $25 price tag, and you might even catch it on sale, as I did.

146081322.review:
Una obra maestra de principio a fin.

El mejor Pixel Art que he visto, una jugabilidad inmejorable, una historia tétrica y profunda que no deja un mal sabor de boca, es que Blasphemous es un 10/10 sin ninguna duda.

Cuenta con un mapa inmenso con muchísimos tipos de quests, coleccionables, distintos tipos de enemigos, objetos clave y un largo etc.

Para completar su historia te bastará con jugarlo durante al menos 5 o 6 horas, pero... Si quieres completar sus distintos finales, conseguir completar todas las quests (que también tienen varios finales), conseguir todos los coleccionables (38 bebés y 44 huesos que hay que buscar por todo el mapa), todas las cuencas de rosario (30 en total, unas repartidas por el mapa y otras por realizar quests), todas los niveles y habilidades de la "mea culpa", mejorar tu barra de salud al máximo, encontrar todos los biliares vacíos y mejorarlos y por último encontrar cada jodido rincón del mapa, te llevará cómo mínimo: de 25 a 35 horas. Todo esto, para conseguir que tu partida esté al 100% de progreso.

Y que decir de los logros, la mayoría son de seguir el progreso de la historia y de tu partida, y para completar los logros más complicados, lo más probable es que tengas que comenzar una nueva partida y empezar otra vez. 

Yo he tardado 45 horas en completar todos los logros, y puedo decir que ha sido difícil, pero me ha encantado.

Si buscas un Souls-like con algún que otro aspecto de metroidvania, este es tu juego, sin duda alguna.

146045836.review:
Overall Score - 6/10

[h1] Disclaimer for those in India [/h1]
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME at its current price. If you check steam's price history, Blasphemous saw a roughly 350% increase in its price, putting it at just about on par with the American USD rate. This is ridiculous as far as regional pricing goes and the game most definitely is NOT worth the current amount of Rs. 1999 (as of Sept. 2023). Buy this game when it's on heavy discount, if at all. Otherwise, just go for something else.

[h3] Ok, game review [/h3]
I could not bring myself to finish this game, there just was not enough of a motive for me to keep playing. I got to around the final boss and though I did have some late game stuff left to explore, I couldn't muster the enthusiasm to invest time into it.

[h3] The Good Stuff [/h3]
The art style is beautiful, especially the creature and character designs. If you're someone who is a fan of gore and just super weird shit, then you're gonna at least have a good time staring at your screen. The environment design ranges from fine to amazing, but the creature designs are definitely what stands out the most. Blasphemous's art is heavily rooted in religious iconography most notably taken from Christianity and it plays around with that concept in some extremely gruesome ways.

The sound design is what really carried the experience for me. It is so good. The OS, combat sounds, creature sounds, and just about everything is top-notch and really helps to immerse in Blasphemous' weird universe.

[h3] The Bad [/h3]
The game tries too damn hard to be edgy, it's gory, gruesome, biblical, and weird, and it'll beat you over the head with it. 

Also why would you use a Blackletter font for a pixel art game?? I get why it was used thematically, but it just made reading item descriptions such a chore, especially considering a lot of the terms are very specific to just Blasphemous. I often misread many words and mostly could not be bothered with reading more than two lines or until I understood what the item did in-game.

The combat and platforming were by far the weakest aspects of the game for me, the combat is just fine when it comes to the regular enemies, other than a few of the enemies which just bring the gameplay down to a halt and sometimes require you to simply tank hits. The boss fights were just okay, I think it took me only about 2-3 tries for most bosses, though some of the late-game boss fights were A LOT better than those in the early to mid-game.

The platforming is my main gripe with this game as the tools given offer such a poor experience while traversing the levels and a majority of this game requires you to traverse large distances to get anywhere. I don't think I enjoyed even a single instance of platforming. A lot of the ledges you need to jump to are also this 2.5D thing which made it confusing to know when you've actually landed on something. There is no flow to the character's movement.

[h1] In Conclusion [/h1]
I had a little bit of fun playing Blasphemous, it would have been an okay experience were it not for the awful platforming. The game progression is also way too obscure and half the time you don't even know where you're supposed to go. It's somehow like Dark Souls 1 but without the beautiful world, lore, and characters. If you're looking for a similar experience to this then I'd suggest Ender Lilies, Ori, Hollow Knight, Dead Cells, Salt and Sanctuary, Shovel Knight, Furi, Katana Zero. Though Blasphemous is a competently made game, I had a lot more of an enjoyable experience playing these other game.

146036699.review:
[h1]Joyful be the heart![/h1]
There are some video games that can be easily said that they go beyond being the source of entertainment. That they reach further, into the field of a fine work of art. One of those games is definitely Blasphemous. Astounding atmosphere and lore, coated with totally beautiful and detailed pixel-art graphic and climatic music, both fitting the in-game world they represent and portray.

This could be enough to classify Blasphemous as a work of art, but one mustn't forget about something equally important as the things I mentioned earlier, which is gameplay and everything surrounding it. It is as polished as the audiovisual side of this game, meaning that we have a lot of abilities and combos to perform, challenging bosses to defeat, various platforming sequences to go through. Level design is superb and, combined with a minimap allowing to put markers etc. on it, makes a player accustomed to the whole area they are currently in.

Cherry on the top are achievements. They are fair, rewarding, and definitely doable. Some of them are easier to get, some are harder, but with enough practice getting 100% achievements doesn't seem like an impossible task at all.

Any cons? Sometimes it's not clear, at least on a first glance, what to do exactly to reach a particular ending or finish a quest, often bound to an achievement. It's a minor inconvenience, in my opinion. It might seem annoying at times, but doesn't take the joy of playing this game. At least it did not in my case.

I definitely recommend Blasphemous. As a fan of the metroidvania genre, playing it was truly a gaming feast and pure pleasure.

146019859.review:
Blasphemous is an absolute holy grail of pixel art and excellent gameplay! From its beautifully grotesque world to its challenging combat, it offers an unholy amount of fun. With its captivating lore, engaging combat, and great level design, this game will keep you hooked for hours if you're a fan of Metroidvanias.

If you explore thoroughly, you'll become quite powerful thanks to all the upgrades you'll find. Don't worry, it remains enjoyable and never gets boring. The balance evens out in NG+ mode, which is the best New Game+ experience I've had in any game. You can choose from three stipulations that completely alter the game's dynamics, keeping each new playthrough fresh.

I also loved the Easter Eggs hidden throughout the game. Also, the ability to unlock skins after completing certain challenges was a nice nod to the past when skins were earned as proof of achievements rather than purchased. Yes, you can buy one skin here too, but still.

Highly recommended. I'm excited for Blasphemous 2!

While difficulty is the name of the game for soulslike and exploration/world connection is the same for metroidvanias this one falls short in that the difficulty is placed almost completely on the clunkiness of the character. The obstacles are almost unavoidable at certain points in the game so you are bound to get damaged from SOMETHING. 145931676.review:
Although I recommend Blasphemous, there are a few caveats that you need to be aware of before jumping in. 

The story the story some how makes Fromsoftware's video game stories as coherent as a children's book. You'll have NPCs spouting terms and events that make no sense in what your'e trying to do in the game, so if story telling is your thing, and you're not into figuring out what the heck went down, this game isn't for you. Also brief aside of the story, ending C, the game's canon ending that apparently leads into the events of the sequel, is missable and missing it requires you to start over or play New Game Plus, but the latter is recommended due to a few bosses in the game are exclusive to New Game Plus. 

Too many of the upgrades are too far off the beaten path and require the usual affair of not being able to access them until you get a tool to reach them, but you get these tools so late that you'll forget about them unless you remember to mark them on your map to come back later. If you expect the game to hand you upgrades, the ones that the game naturally gives you, or the ones that you can immediately get as soon as you stray off the beaten path is minimal. I ended the game with like two magical abilities (Prayers) and one or two passive abilities (Hearts). So don't expect to have that many toys to play with unless you either take the time to go back every now and then to look for them when you get a new traversal tool, look them up, or play New Game Plus since all traversal tools that you unlock (some are optional, but required to get certain items and abilities) are carried over, so you can just go to every side path and get nearly everything in the game.

FInally, the movement and platforming is a bit clunky, not the most terrible thing I've played, but it feels a little jank at times. 

With all those caveats out of the way, the combat is fun, parrying feels very good, and presents a fair challenge. The design of the enemies are cool especially the bosses. Environments are cool as well, even though a bit boring sometimes (looking at you Jundo).

Blasphemous is rough around the edges in terms of story, upgrade progression, and movement, but if you can get passed that, then I recommend you give it a try.

The artstyle is instantly captivating. The gothic architecture, religious elements, and gore all painted an image of medieval dystopian fantasy. It's a unique setting that I don't think I've ever seen anything similar to before. The game is worth playing just for the visuals alone.

Combat never felt unfair. There are many tools at your disposal to use against the variety of common enemies - equipment, prayers (basically spells), plus the different ways to use your sword. All the boss fights felt unique which is a plus. They really test your understanding of the combat and movement system.

Only complaint I have is with the jumping puzzles as the hitboxes of the spike pits are a bit wider than they should be. Dying just by being next to them was a major source of frustration. However it is optional content. Overall they were still fun and did not feel overtly unfair.

145833591.review:
The Righteous:
[list][*]Good level design.
[*]Creative art direction with some truly curious boss designs.
[*]Balanced combat difficulty with minimal penalty for dying. 
[*]Good number of secrets and some clever puzzles.
[*]Fitting soundtrack that is generally quite good.[/list]

The Profane: 
[list][*]A couple of important progression items require very convoluted steps to find.
[*]Some encounters trigger during very specific windows of opportunity that can be missed. There are at least two situations where accepting or equipping an item is irreversible, which locks you out of completing certain objectives.
[*]Some objects have weird hit boxes. Ladders can be tricky to grab while jumping and to avoid grabbing during combat.[/list]

Final Judgement: 

Blasphemous is worthy of its positive ratings. Like any successful Metroidvania its level progression is fun and complex, with plenty of secrets to uncover. Boss fights are simple but challenging, though not as punishing as Hollow Knight or Souls games, which I personally appreciate. Combat is pretty standard: mostly hack n' slash with some semi-useful prayer spells that I frequently forgot to use.  

On the other hand there are disappointingly several ways that the designers lock you out of accessing certain content in a given run due to some very unclear or needlessly strict conditions.

145823312.review:
People can be very opinionated about "metroidvanias". And they're very subjective; some people like specific types of combat, movement, upgrades, and exploring. But for me, Blasphemous checks all the boxes and keeps me coming back year after year thanks to the creepy and beautiful Catholic and gothic art style. There's not even much I can complain about... some have complained about the spikes or falling in bottomless pits; but there are enough save points (just the right amount), and also you're not punished that much for dying. It just forces you to be careful at times. 

The music, while atmospheric and blending in, fits the game perfectly. 

It's worth multiple plays through; the only complaint I really have is that to 100% the game and get all achievements can be confusing (specific order of operations and ignoring certain things is a requirement) -- I had to use a guide to make sure everything fired.

While I've "finished" the game, there's a lot more that I have left to explore -- and I'm very excited to do so! The art is beautiful, both in the scenery as well as the enemy/character designs. The gameplay holds up really well overall, with a couple awkward mechanics (like jumping off of enemies for a little boost).

The OST is quite wonderful, as is the voice acting. The difficulty is considerable, but not too unreasonable if you have some experience with games like this.

The storytelling/worldbuilding is so incredibly souls-esque which could be good or bad depending on your taste -- while the world is immersive, the narrative can get a bit confusing at times, especially if you don't pay attention to all the details. But that's what can also make it so enticing -- might make you want to watch a video on the story or find every last thing in the game.

Really solid! Excited to play the DLC and the sequel. (9/10)

145702233.review:
Right, so, an overtly souls-like metroidvania sounded like "not my thing", and maybe it still isn't "my thing", but like... the game is GOOD good, so, who even cares?

Like, not to bury the lede, there's a lot about the game that I inherently don't necessarily enjoy - the controls are maybe a LITTLE sluggish, the game's got the whole "drop stuff on death" mechanic that I don't tend to like - generally dying is already punishment enough in this type of game - and the game is, interestingly, not necessarily HARD so much as PUNISHING - in that, like, instant death pits and spikes are EVERYWHERE and that's, like. Not good form for a metroidvania, guys! Ehh. The platforming, also, is generally not great - you don't have a platforming moveset so it tends to just involve a lot of awkward jumping, wall clinging, and ledge grabbing, but it's not the highlight of the game anyways.

And then, aesthetically, the game is absolutely not for me - way too gory and gross, even if there's something... satisfying, about all the twisted christian imagery, eheh. And the lore and story... exist. Lore is presented in a really annoying way in the inventory screen and I stopped reading it after a while because the actual dialogue is... so overwrought my brain can't be bothered to parse it. The plot happens. I guess. I dunno, don't really care about it but it sure does happen.

Right, so, all the nitpicks out of the way - I'm kinda shocked at how good the game actually feels to play, in spite of all its limitations? Combat is built really well around your swordplay, your parry and your dodge, with some ingredients of positioning and platforming in some instances, and you get your spells and some rad sword upgrades to complete your toolkit - never really used the horribly slow charge attack, and the blood projectile only saw minor use, but other than that, like, basically every combat option I was given I found some use for and that's both. So cool and so RARE.

And the enemy designs remain pretty consistently diverse - there's maybe a small handful of enemy reskins across its 50+ standard mobs, not to mention the bosses which all feel distinct and interesting, both in their fighting style and their gimmicks. Again, there's maybe one or two fights that feel kiiiind of scuffed - and, shockingly, I'd say the (standard) final boss is one of the easiest fights in the game - but in general they're all pretty dang fun to fight.

The game's also... not, that hard, necessarily. Like I said. Like, the bosses are pretty great, but... during standard play, you're hardly gonna notice because you're not gonna die to most of the basegame bosses, like, ever. I sucked and I still beat most of them first try, because you have so much health and so much healing and such a bounty of options at hand that you're rarely forced to -learn- fights - I had to come back doing the no potions achievement to REALLY face the bosses, I feel like. The DLC bosses trend a lot harder, of course, especially the ones on the true ending path, and I DID have to, like, learn those fights, so, I feel like they got a better sense of balance the more game they released.

Which, like, isn't it super cool that there's just three whole free DLC expansions? Much akin to hollow knight, though frankly, I think the inclusions here are meatier and, on the whole, better. New game plus with bonus challenges and an entire new set of bosses tied to anew quest, a full-on boss rush mode, a crossover with bloodstained and a set of platforming gauntlets alongside it, an entire new story path, including a new zone, a few new bosses, and new animations and cutscenes? That's a LOT!

...granted, not all of the DLC inclusions are actually, like, great. The Bloodstained DLC is especially egregious as, as previously mentioned, platforming is NOT this game's forte and most of these platforming gauntlets SUCK as a result. Do you like waiting around on slow moving platforms for 2-3 minutes? Where one mistake sends you into the instakill spikes? Haaaaave fuuuuun~ Yeah, no, they're utter tripe and kind of a - heh - stain on the game as a whole. I have to wonder if they're bad on purpose to make Bloodstained look worse compared to Blasphemous - chill out, guys, Bloodstianed did that just fine on its own. The new area added in the DLC is also pretty trash, though - way way WAY too powerful mobs, huge screens full of an annoying environmental hazard that, despite this, have almost nothing of note on them... complete dud in my books. I can take or leave the boss rush and the NG+ penitences, they're content for someone else who isn't me to enjoy :V

Oh and I should at least mention the map design and exploration, which is another major highlight - the world opens up in three major directions pretty much immediately - and then after a chokepoint in the middle of the game, busts pretty wide open for the second half as well - and the map's naturally designed to loop back around and open up shortcuts - on top of two different fast travel systems you eventually unlock - so it's got both convenience and exploration down to a T.  Lots of little side-paths and secrets, fake walls you can generally stumble upon naturally (but there is eventually an item to help track them down more easily), I'm generally not a fan of when metroidvania maps make you keep track of everything yourself but it's not too bad here. I dunno, the world's just satisfying to explore. Each zone isn't too terribly big, there's just, a lot of them, so things stay fresh throughout!

I do have my criticisms, obviously, but I ended up pretty well engrossed in this one and even went out of my way to 100% it - achievement-wise, anyways, though I did at least see myself through all the DLC bosses and true ending added, so I've seen all the unique content the game has to offer - and for the price, you do get quite a good bit, on top of the game just being, again - good! It's really good. I'll check out the sequel next year though I think I've had enough of this game for now. Oh wait there's a rando wellnevermindthenoops.

¡Blasphemous es un juego que realmente me ha cautivado desde el primer momento! Desde el principio, quedé impresionada por lo increíblemente divertido que es. La trama es envolvente, y lo que más me fascinó es la inclusión de múltiples finales, lo que le da un valor de repetición significativo.

La diversidad de bosses es simplemente asombrosa. Cada uno de ellos presenta un desafío único y emocionante, y las batallas son intensas y llenas de adrenalina. La estrategia es clave, y me encontré disfrutando cada encuentro, incluso cuando me vencían una y otra vez. La sensación de logro al finalmente superar a un boss es inigualable.

Además, la atmósfera del juego es realmente impresionante. Los gráficos y la música se combinan para crear un mundo oscuro y sombrío que te sumerge por completo en la experiencia. Los detalles visuales y la atención al diseño son evidentes en cada rincón del mapa.

Blasphemous ha superado mis expectativas en todos los sentidos, y estoy emocionada por en el futuro jugar el Blasphemous 2. Si mantienen la misma calidad y creatividad que encontré en el primer juego, estoy segura de que será una experiencia igualmente emocionante. En definitiva, Blasphemous es un título imprescindible para cualquier amante de los videojuegos que busque diversión y desafío. ¡No puedo esperar a ver qué nos depara el futuro de esta increíble franquicia!

145653623.review:
Después de muchos años sin viciarme en ningún título en particular me encontré con Blasphemous. Soy un completista amante de los metroidvania y comencé a jugar sin mayor información, sólo un par de trailers con los que me topé y vi sin muchos ánimos, nada que me hiciera presagiar tremenda experiencia y buena impresión que me generó este título. Mi primera partida fue con esa precaución característica de los plataformeros en los que vas midiendo las mecánicas, analizando los movimientos y el comportamiento del mundo de Custodia. Cuando cae el primer boss delante del Penitente me fui directamente a machacar el botón de ataque sobre él, tremendo error, morí un par de veces hasta pillarle el ritmo y poder manejarme con los patrones, la esquiva aún no la comprendía muy bien y los matraces son limitados y te dejan al descubierto unos instantes lo que te obliga a no abusar de ellos. Posterior a este enfrentamiento y en la medida que me adentraba más en el juego podía admirar y embelesarme de sus paisajes tan bien logrados, se siente lo lúgubre de algunas localizaciones y lo sacro en otras, además la música complementa muy armónicamente con cada instancia, aunque muy cortos encontré los ritmos y al poco rato las tonadas se vuelven repetitivas aunque no es un gran punto en contra. Completé esta partida sin buscar guías ya que quería saber cuánto lograba obtener y el resultado fue súper grato.
En mi segunda partida (NG+) fui más en profundidad con los rezos y la build del rosario, experimentaba en cada rincón de lo escenarios y me di el tiempo de leer las descripciones de los objetos y recolectar todo lo que fuese posible, descubrir todos los finales y probar las penitencias. Todo ésto me dejó una experiencia bastante agradable, el juego tiene mucho contenido y es muy rejugable lo que te lleva a partidas completamente distintas, utilizando las cuentas, corazones y rezos que en algún momento ignoraste, además de sus finales múltiples que te dejan un buen sabor de satisfacción.
Mi última partida (NG) la jugué para para completar la lista de logros y fue en ésta dónde me sentí como el real penitente. Las mecánicas ya las dominaba por completo y podía alternar entre la guardia, esquives y saltos para derrotar a los enemigos los cuales ya no tenían oportunidad alguna. Logré avanzar y derrotar de forma muy simple a casi todos los jefes (te odio Esdras). Ya los modelados y ambientaciones me parecían una obra de arte, la excelente historia está muy bien hilada y se siente auténtica, los personajes y sus diálogos te hacen conectarte con el todo del lore y el español ostia (por primera vez xD) es el mejor idioma en el que se puede disfrutar esta gran obra. Se nota el tremendo esfuerzo y cariño que todo el equipo ha puesto en este tremendo juegazo. Gracias por The Game Kitchen por hacerme sentir nuevamente esa magia de disfrutar como un niño un excelente juego y me han ayudado a volver a interesarme a explorar nuevos títulos de éste genero y gracias al maestro Kentaro Miura, la influencia de su obra maestra repercutirá en el tiempo.

145646414.review:
After trying to play blasphemous 2 I feel compelled to finally leave a review recommending this rather than the sequel. This is by far my favorite metroidvania and one of my favorite games of all time. It easily has the best integration of dark souls elements with a 2d metroidvania. It hits the right spot of atmosphere, difficulty, and no hand holding. The art style is iconic and foreboding. The difficulty is high at times but often gives you other challenges so you can later return where you're struggling. There is no quest log telling you what to do but the game allows you to mark out your map so you can figure out quests for yourself. NG+ also adds "penances" which change how you approach playing the game.

Overall I completely recommend this game and would say to not play the sequel as it feels like a watered down experience that lacks the atmosphere and difficulty that makes this game great

145618955.review:
★★★

This game has great lore and worldbuilding, and a significant number of glaring fundamental issues. The combat is pretty decent, but it is hampered by mediocre hitboxes and gameplay issues. This game heavily relies on artificial difficulty, where they increase the number of enemies or the number of environmental hazards in an area to make it harder. There are also enemies in a later area that spawn out of thin air and can spawn directly on your character, making you take free damage from an enemy that you cannot even see. Similarly, the boss encounters are incredibly weak imo. Most bosses have a very small moveset of 3-4 moves that they relentlessly spam and later in the encounter, the bosses will just increase how quickly they use this repetitive moveset. It makes most fights very boring and while most bosses are very well-designed, their fights don't have the same effect. One simple gameplay mechanic that frustrated me to hell was the fact that your character is knocked down when taking damage in most cases. The bosses take advantage of this knockdown by spamming more of their attacks while you're knocked down, which in most cases would be fine, but it seems like the knockdown is an animation lock causing you to not be able to move or parry while you're down. You also will likely need a guide for this game because all of the item descriptions or questlines are incredibly cryptic and its often near impossible to determine what to do with specific quest items. Finally, while lorewise the final boss of the game is interesting, the actual encounter is a massive letdown due to the fight being terribly boring/uninteresting in phase 1 and gimmicky to an extent that it becomes frustrating in phase 2. Overall, I still enjoyed my time with this game, but I think that there are many gameplay aspects that don't feel right and I hope that they are fixed in Blasphemous 2.

145578613.review:
¿Alguna vez en tu vida te ha parecido la religión católica in simbolo de interés? 

si no es así, da igual, te vas a meter por el culo blasphemous a tal nivel que por la gracia de Dios verás a la virgen maría y dirás que su propio martirio la ha ensartado con una espada.

Blasphemous es un metroidvania donde manejamos a un señor de estos de gorrico de pico que se parece a cierto grupo de odio (pero que no van por ahí los tiros, que realmente es un penitente de estos del gorrico morado) , donde "El milagro", nos brinda de una misión dentro del mundo de Blasphemous que no contaré mas porque jaja spoilers. 

Blasphemous es uno de estos jueguicos que hacen que todo el mapa esté conectado de una manera osolutamente maravillosa donde tendrás un montón de objetos a recoger que alimentarán la historia de los personajes que te vas encontrando, mejoras, jefes y plataformeillo rico.

El diseño de niveles es una locura, se puede apreciar claramente como cada incio de una nueva zona es una manera gradual de entender qué enemigos te vas a encontrar y como poco a poco la cosa se va complicando, como sistema de combate tienes tu combito de toda la vida, los parrys (Que son una puta maravilla) y algunos combos mas que se van mejorando con el tiempo. 

Si vas a jugarlo te recomiendo que te pierdas en el mapa, que explores todo, la curiosidad mató al gato, y al penitente también, pero posiblemente encontrarás algun objeto que digas "Hostia puta que maravilla" o desbloquearás algún objeto que te venga realmente bien. 

De coleccionables va bastante bien, y el sistema de muerte es similar a cualquier souls like, pero aquí en vez de perder el "dinero" del juego, vas acumulando culpa que empieza a enraizar tu barra de "magia" y evita que puedas lanzar todas las habilidades que quieras. 

En resumen. 

¿Deberías jugar Blasphemous?

Yo digo: Métetelo por el culo a la velocidad del sonido.

145564487.review:
It's one of those games that makes me wish Steam had a "star" system instead of a simple "recommend/don't recommend" system. 
The Pros:
-The environment and art design is pretty cool, with some unique character concepts. 
-Thematic music and character voice acting
-A cool-looking level up and upgrade system that seems to naturally scale. 
-Some fun bosses each with unique mechanics

The cons:
-The platforming just sucks. It is absolutely atrocious. The wall-jumping mechanics are the weirdest I've ever experienced. In order to jump "up" the wall, you have to jump up, out, and back in in a crazy arc. Jumping from ladder to ladder is brutal; there's an almost full second delay from where you press 'up' and your character actually grabs on to the ladder. 

-Level design is pretty poor. There're either no save points anywhere or three save points all clustered together in one spot, making each one kind of useless. So when you inevitably die far away from one when doing some exploring, it's just absolutely brutal to have to go all the way back through trap-valley to try and collect your dead body. 

-The traps placed, while unique, are often brutal with janky hit frames. The spikes in this game are the absolute worst. If even your pinkie toe touches the spikes, your character suddenly teleports to an impaled state. 


I'll probably finish the game if I get the time, just because I spent the money on it. But yeah, wouldn't recommend. The gameplay mechanics just suck. They're clunky and obviously need refinement.

Update: My above review stands as is. I'm reaching the end and the platforming is just the worst. They're not trying to make it difficult, they're just trying to be annoying and kill you. Floors crumble out of nowhere and lead to spike pits, every improper jump is punished with an insta-kill spike pit. Very disappointing, especially since the boss fights are so good.

145527103.review:
After the release of Blasphemous 2 I finally decided to give Blasphemous a try, and believe me I tried to like it. The controls felt a little wonky to me in the beginning, but every game has a rough start. Did that feeling ever change? No.

Do you like a lot of challenging platforming, even tho the controls may not be the best in comparison to other metroidvanias? This is the game for you. 
Do you like challenging bosses and new movement abilities, that make the game a fluent experience? Absolutely stay away from this game. 

The bossfights (so far) are not hard at all; most of them are just attack spam with a few parries or dodges in between, the hardest part was to get into the controls in the span of the first hour. The final straw for me was the Mourning and Havoc area. It's so anti-fun, I can't even put it into words. I like a good challenge, but this is not challenging. It's annoying.
Another bad thing, in my opinion, are the quests, general progression and items. When did it become the golden standard to make every questline as confusing as possible? Why am I not allowed to find new relics by just casually playing the game? Everything is a riddle now, often you do not know where to go and I don't want to glue my eyes on a guide to enjoy a game. Sorry.

The graphics however are great, really interesting designs everywhere. I don't like the pixelated style over a longer period of time, but that's not a real problem, just personal preference of other styles. I've also read that you get locked out of some endings by timed events, which put me off even more. I guess this game is just not for me.

145525100.review:
Getting the obligatory praise for the stunning visuals  out of the way- this game feels like a draft of a game rather than a finished product.

 I can see the combat being serviceable in a demo, but the game utterly fails in evolving and expanding it's mechanics in a meaningful way, going so far as to reusing enemies and patterns to make up for the lack of an arsenal the player has.

 You would think a game with such lackluster encounters would at least make the traversal the real challenge then, but sadly this is the game's weakest aspect. For most of it, the platforming is absurdly simple, and only serves wake you up when getting bored of the abruptly placed insta-death traps and copy/paste encounters around the world.
 One good example being towards the end of the game, where they decided to place a checkpoint between two moving platforms over a death pit. The challenge is simply waiting for the platform to be close enough to jump on, then waiting for the next one to align. No gameplay, no challenge, and not even the relief of escaping the obstacles for even one brief moment.

 What's worse, is that the game also tries to be a metroidvania, leaving certain collectibles behind closed doors for later. A type of level design I'm usually fond of, as it makes you engage in learning your environment and tests your observation. Sadly there's rarely ever a satisfying reward behind these doors, leaving you with a feeling of having wasted time by playing through the exact same drawn-out platforming sequences again, without the novelty of seeing it for the first time.

 The only thing really motivating you to keep playing the game is the intriguing world and promise that your efforts will be rewarded. Sadly that is also used against you, as the game rarely lets you interact with characters in meaningful ways while also frequently locking you out from progressing their story lines with arbitrary invisible counters that eventually kill them off.
 While I usually appreciate developers who require you pay attention and engage in the world in order to get the best outcome, it feels unfair when nothing is clearly communicated or telegraphed. It completely robs you of the immersion to rely on outside information (searching wikis, guides or playing the game multiple times) in order to get rewarded.

There's so much more I'd like to say about this game, but it's already wasted enough of my time.

To anyone playing with a Steam Deck, if you want the Steam Cloud save to work, you need to run it in Compatibility Mode... otherwise, it won't sync with other devices (in my case, my Windows laptop)... At review time, the Steam Deck is running Proton 8.0-3...

(In my case, I started on the Steam Deck and my Windows is blank)... If you want to keep your savefile, copy your save on the Deck at [u]~/.config/unity3d/TheGameKitchen/Blasphemous/Savegames[/u] and copy it to your laptop at [u]C:\Users\%username%\AppData\LocalLow\TheGameKitchen\Blasphemous[/u]

After that, run the game on your laptop to Cloud Sync it... Turning on the Compatibility Mode on your Deck will download the Proton and your Windows save...
=========================================
Review the game? Its not like Hollow Knight where you can do a bunch of quick fancy dodges and counterhits on everything... Its slow and heavy where you need to think how to dodge well and time the attack...

145371915.review: It's been a while since I played but I remember being disappointed after hearing all the praise for the game. If I recall correctly, the Metroidvania backtracking was too much and too time-consuming, the game rarely gave you an idea of where you were supposed to go, and the combat was too difficult in a clunky/weird way and not a fun/challenging way. I'm an avid enjoyer of both souls-likes and metroidvania so I'm the ideal demographic for this game but couldn't be bothered to do all the side content after getting the first ending, and that's after forcing myself to beat it in hopes that it would get better. The game's setting, art and lore is incredible, but it couldn't carry the problems with the gameplay. I'm writing this review now because the sequel is out and I want people looking to start the series with this game to know it doesn't live up to the hype.

145368391.review:
Blasphemous is a great metroidvania that borrows a lot of design elements from Dark Souls. The pixel art and animations are incredibly detailed and excellent and the voice acting is also very good. A lot of effort went into making this a pretty fun game.

However, I can think of a few things I'd like to see changed for improved QoL:

  - Some of the relics should be equipped by default. There's no reason to have to waste a 
    slot/pause and switch just to be able to talk to the dead or be immune to poison.

  - Names and descriptions should be simplified. Extreme verbosity is part of the world but it's 
    a pain to have to sift through so much cruft to find out an item gives you increased health.

  - Checkpoints in the Miriam platforming sections would be nice because falling into instant 
    death spikes feels unfair considering how awful the ladder hit boxes can be here.

There are a few other slightly clunky mechanics, but I can overlook most of them. Good buy on sale.

145345129.review:
After finishing the game WITHOUT a guide, thus being part of the whopping [b]SIXTEEN[/b] percent of players who got the (brutally unceremonious and objectively disrespectful) "b" ending, I can't help but being puzzled by the overwhelming appreciation this game got.

I think too many people hastily recommended this game for what it [i]promises to be[/i], rather than for what it really is.

This game is obsessed with two concepts
1) difficulty for the sake of difficulty (the sorry embarassment that is the "new game+", with its plethora of contrived handicaps, is a further and laughably blatant indication of this)
2) the less information is given to the player, in order to advance in a meaningful way in the game, the better

If these two points sound like your cup of tea, by all means feel free to indulge, for about 25 to 30 hours, in a competently written metroidvania, set in an ultra-bleak world, filled with religious atrocities ad nauseam.

Otherwise, well... feel free to look elsewhere for better ways to spend your time.

Of course, not everything in this game is perplexing: for example, pressing buttons on your controller will prompt a corresponding action performed by the main character.

145285146.review:
I struggle to place whether design elements are mean-spirited or incompetent, though it's probably a mix of both. Which is a shame, since there's obviously a lot to like here, aesthetically. The art and music are gorgeous. Traversing environments, in a vacuum, is fun. However, the whole picture of combat and the nature of controlling your character is straight up rubbish. I don't think anyone on the development team actually played this. Trying to grab ledges and hanging onto walls has got to be among the worst frustration I've ever experienced in a video game, while in combat. There's so much unforeseen circumstance waiting to screw you over. If you have any reservations and care deeply about the core package of movement in a platforming game, don't buy this.

---edit---

After playing through what feels like the majority of the game, I can safely say nothing's improved. In fact, it's gotten worse. Everything that irked me in my first few hours has snowballed into unfathomable levels of bullshit. Encountering later, newer obstacles makes me feel as though development was an afterthought. There appears to be no proper or optimal way to manage anything, as if the player character and the environment were developed irrespective of one another. This is exacerbated by the game's propensity to copy and paste enemies when it didn't quite hit that threshold of unfairness the developers were looking for. Nothing is patterned well either, and otherwise fair encounters are rendered wild and unpredictable. Not to mention the unfettered, bonkers nonsense that incurs from having no grace period of invulnerability, after being knocked around. This leads to a whole host of issues as you get pummeled across boards like a beach ball, until you're dead and miles away from wherever the fuck you just were. Also, whose brilliant idea was it to require an input to get through the death screen? Like, really, what the hell is the point of that? It becomes an unrelenting annoyance after dying to all this aforementioned garbage fifty times in a row. Especially, when it won't accept controller inputs and I have to reach over and press something on my keyboard; way to take my ass out of the experience. This game is a mess and I can't, for the life of me, understand why it's received so well. I want to like this game. I should like this game, but I don't. I can't recommend it either. Go play Grime instead.

El juego cuenta con más de 50 enemigos y bastantes bosses (más aún con los DLC instalados ya con el juego), deberás ir explorando todo el mapa para obtener tanto mejoras o habilidades para la espada, como para el personaje, así como mejorarte tu barra de vida o fervor y la cantidad de matraces con los que curarte, los bosses no son tan difíciles, más aún si vas mejorando tus stats cada vez que puedes. El juego además cuenta con 3 finales (2 principales A/B y otro intermedio añadido con un DLC) por lo que tendrás juego para rato.
Los DLC bueno, añaden bosses, skins para el protagonista, nuevas zonas y demás pero... Era necesario el DLC "Strife & Ruin"? El personaje se las da durante todo el juego de macho alfa, matando a todo dios y pasando de todo el mundo para que en el DLC active el modo "simp" y ayude a una tal Miriam con su basura de desafíos contrarreloj, si contrarreloj, en un puto Souls, no le veo el sentido. Por lo demás es un juegazo más que disfrutable.

145169783.review:
Great metrovania/dark souls game but the way the game is laid out is off. Every upgrade in this game is gated by secrets that can be missed. If you play this game mark your map so you know where to go back from.  The dlc content can be convoluted and it all requires back tracking. Also very little is explained which is ok if the mechanics are intuitive. For the life of me I dont understand why Dark souls like games don't adopt the same system of if you unlock a shrine you can port over there. Stop making porting to shrines something you have to earn! Good grief! PS tithe at the church because it provides considerable upgrades. 

The end bosses/dlc bosses that provide the hardest content are can be a bit cheap and shows the developers honest attempt to recreate dark souls like bosses but what they miss is that in dark souls those bosses have many ways to be beaten. In the game that dynamic is missing and most likely to be said bosses will require you to find secrets to upgrade your character like certain prayers or beads. Or of course you can just git gud and became a no hit player. 

Ultimately I dont like that power level of the character is gated by discovery more than combat and challenging battles. Hopefully they struck a better balance in the sequel. 

In conclusion, a solid game that misses being truly great due to the above design issues. However if you fight the DLC bosses and the ending C bosses and put the work in to discover your power level you will have a great time.  The developers are close to making something special. Looking forward to the sequel to see if what they have learned.

145148470.review:
I had a lot of fun playing Blasphemous. The art style and heavy Spanish and Catholic influence is greatly appreciated and gives the game a character that I've never seen in another game before. Bosses are designed as if by an expert painter from centuries past.  

The gameplay itself is relatively simple, but enjoyable: 

- Level design was interesting. You would often find shortcuts back to the start of the level or to another level that seemed far away or unreachable, making the world feel interconnected instead of linear. 
- Character quests were vague, but not so vague as to require a guide every step of the way. You simply had to pay attention to dialogue and item descriptions to deduce the next step. 
- All spells (prayers) had a specific usecase, not one spell felt weak or obsolete if you acquired a new one. 
- Items always felt useful. Every time you found an item, you knew it would be helpful in some way, not more garbage to fill up your inventory screen (like crafting materials for weak consumables in other games). 
- Power-ups feel meaningful every step of the way.
- Tons of secrets to discover and replayability with NG+ challenge modes.
- The game doesn't cop out of letting you become straight up invincible with the right setup. 

However, the game could get annoying or even infuriating at times: 

- Fast travelling between save points is locked behind a 50k purchase, which essentially means that you will not have it until you have already traversed most of the map. Moreover, it's not clearly stated that fast travel is even an option if you spend that amount of money. It just seems you're throwing your money down a pit, until you suddenly get a feature that you should have at the very least by the middle of the game. As well, 50k is incredibly hard to come by without exploits, because most enemies drop no more than 800 gold. Crazy. 
- Platforming can be extremely buggy. The Penitent will get stuck going down ladders or even refuse to grab them altogether, plummeting to his death. He will refuse to ledge-grab on platforms he "missed" by a few pixels. And don't start me on lantern hopping. It's used for pretty much a few optional locations in the game, so I have no idea why it's even there, it makes no sense, and if you have the DLC, it actually becomes one of the worst features in the game. About that...
- I hope whoever designed Miriam's challenges has to wipe his ass with a Carolina Reaper for penance. The game was clearly not designed with precise platforming in mind, so timed platforming challenges are straight up bullshit. Also, who the fuck thought it would be fun to put 45-second auto-scroller sections in a timed platforming challenge??? Holy shit, dude. I think I lost 5 years of my life trying to beat these challenges, for real. 
- This is more of a pet-peeve of mine than anything else, but it's kind of annoying that the beads'/spells' effects aren't immediately visible when you check the inventory screen and you actually have to scroll down a little bit every time.

Anyway, I hope these issues are worked on in Blasphemous 2, in the meantime, I highly recommend this game, it's a work of art.

145074714.review:
Just finished it. It was an okay adventure, but I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

Good things:
-Art, sound, and setting are stylistic and extremely high quality
-Overall, gameplay is functional and solidly average

Bad things:
-The story, cutscenes, and most of the in-game text are incomprehensible
-Many of the puzzle rooms have obscure solutions and will probably require referencing the internet. Thankfully none are related to necessary items
-Movement controls are too stiff
-Character movement is unusually slow for this style of game. Fast travel between savepoints helps, but the way to unlock it is optional and easily missed
-There are way too many slow environmental traps and elevators whose only challenge is forcing the player to wait. They make the already-slow traversal much more of a chore than it should be
-A lot of rooms open to a tiny ledge that drops to a chasm. If you slide into the doorway or walk in while not paying attention, it's instant death
-This one's minor but.. the death screen says "Press any button to continue" and will only accept keyboard inputs regardless of the control scheme. The developer acknowledged this bug 4 years ago, but it's still here. (https://steamcommunity.com/app/774361/discussions/1/2952595757891413830/)

145073950.review:
Janky controls: sometimes character grabs the ledges when I don't want to, sometimes it does not when there's a ledge (when you are not coming at it exactly from the side), dodge attack does not always trigger (ye-ye skill issue)
Inconsistent annoying mechanics: sometimes you can dodge through enemies and projectiles, sometimes your can't, and there's no clear indication for it. Some attacks are parryable, some you can only block, some you can neither block nor parry. Some projectiles can be destroyed, some can't.
No reasonable fast travel: the are only a couple of spots that you can teleport between and the map takes forever to traverse due to respawning enemies with contact damage and environment/traps that slow you down.
Boss fights are interesting, although they have the same inconsistent mechanics. Why do I need to watch the same boss cutscene every time before the fight?
