145039594.review:
Having completed the game I stand by everything here but there's more:
The game is awfully badly paced, the easiest bosses come last, you have to use viridiana for an achievement so just use her as soon as possible. Final boss has no telegraphs. It's not about experience in the genre, it's not even about memorizing the attack pattern, you just have to hope your block won't end too soon when you guess her next move. The platforming sequences with clunky slow and non-responsive controls are more common in the latter half.
The final final miniboss of the game is literally right after the final boss just as padding to close out some sort of a story? Achievement for 100% is locked behind also completing some random DLC sidequest which is just about the dumbest thing... You can tell a lot of love went into this game, just not in the areas that matter.

Today was the last drop. I wanted to like this game, really did. But these beginner game developer/designer mistakes are simply intolerable.

1) Not all the controls are taught to you through-out the course of the game. When you pick up and item and want to read the description of it to determine whether it's worth equiping or not, sometimes the part of the description that's important is off-screen. If you want to read that part, you'll have to know how to scroll that description. Hint: scroll-wheel does NOT work. Oh and if you wanted to check the controls mid-game?

2) There is no pause menu, no settings menu, you have no ability to adjust anything regarding the game while you're in-game, only in the start-up screen. Want to adjust the audio? Restart the game. Video settings? Restart the game. Check or change controls? Re. Start. The. Game. Alternatively you have to alt-tab out of the game to google the controls.

3) Speaking of alt-tabbing, don't. The game does NOT care whether it's in focus or not. It will continue to accept input even if another application is in the foreground and focused. This means that if you alt-tab to write a message to your friend or type anything anywhere, some of those letters you're typing may be accepted by the game as input. In my case, which is today's last drop, I started up the game, and while waiting for it to load (which takes absolute ages given the relatively tiny size of the game) I was chatting. The game accepted those inputs, navigated to the game save menu AND DELETED MY ENTIRE PROGRESS.

Aside from the meta problems above, the gameplay is okay for the most part. I'll just point out a couple of them that negatively stood out.

4) Mechanics seems to be misnamed or just poorly implemented sometimes, specifically parry. It's not really a parry, it's a block. For all the encounters I've had in the game (about 25% in) there were only 2 enemies against which there was an actual parry response, everywhere else it's just a block. Misnomer at best but still slightly annoying.

4.1) More nails in the coffin for parry, it has basically no place in this game. The timing window for some attacks seem intuitive but when you use that same intuition for other attacks, it just let's the attack through either before you even take the parry stance. You simply have to get hit or die a couple of times to memorize the timing window for each parriable attack, but still annoying. In any case, there's almost no point in using this instead of dashing behind the enemy whenever possible, you'll probably forget you even have this ability.

5) Sluggish controls in general. There's no chaining or cancelling actions. There seems to be a cooldown a little bit after almost every action you can take during which you may not start another action. Pacing of the game strongly focuses on the platforming, for which the deficiencies the controls have are most apparent (and abhorent). For some this might be the "real" experience, to me this is just annoying.

6) The hitboxes are completely broken. There's just no regard to what is shown to you on screen. Oh a projectile flew 2 player character heights above you? Yea that hit you. A lazer passes through you? Nah you're good fam.
https://youtu.be/LcJVK4qTnz0

But it's okay guys, the dev included like 4 completely redundant CRT shaders taken from their first course on how to write shaders or stolen from shadertoy! No seriously, some good things about this game: The bosses and puzzles are fun, the pixel art is lovely, sound design is good and the story is enjoyable. I'll keep playing the game for those reasons alone, despite all the issues I listed, simply because it's a good enough experience to be worth the trouble (once you've been made aware of the broken-ness and can effectively avoid it, that is). It is however NOT anywhere near worth 25 USD or EUR. At most this could be a 10 dollar game, and that's pushing it. I got it for 6.50 that's the only reason this game didn't immediately get refunded. It's not just unpolished, it's unfinished. This should be a private alpha, not a release for 25 bucks.

145021601.review:
I really wanted to enjoy this game. The style is off the charts and everyone I know that's played it has said it was really good. Well with the second one coming out I finally got around to it and it's... disappointing.

TLDR: the platforming and parry are super finicky and end up turning the solid combat and beautiful aesthetic into an exercise in frustration.

I beat the first boss/enemy handily and it felt pretty good; in general melee combat DOES feel pretty good! Except the parry is finicky. That's the word of the day in fact. My sword touching the enemy weapon isn't automatically a parry, instead it requires precision timing with no visible cue, and as such becomes unreliable. And with how little warning a lot of enemy attacks give, getting that timing down is frustrating at best. Especially because early on there's a type of ranged enemy that are constantly placed on tiny platforms you have to make several jumps to get to while they repeatedly throw tracking projectiles at you and you *don't have a block*. You have to parry them, which is, again, finicky. Sekiro succeeds at making the player parry everything because the visual *always* matches the timing. Blasphemous fails in my eyes because of the opposite.

Also hey, you know what's normal in a platformer? Jumping from rope to rope, or in this case ladder to ladder! You know what *isn't* normal in these cases? The ladders having itty bitty basically frame perfect hitboxes with large visuals! It makes it very confusing and frustrating to see the character in a place where they could very clearly grab the ladder and don't. I guess that's why it's normally ropes. That visual-gameplay dissonance was far more frustrating to me than the combat. It also extends to things like landing on platforms and the aforementioned parrying. In general the game tries to merge precision platforming with tough combat and its always the former that ruins it for me. Why does our character slide a few frames on stopping if you want me to be precise?

Spikes are an instant death. Cool, whatever, platformer things. Except they go with the soulslike school of level design: dying sends you back to a checkpoint (which are fairly rare) and respawns all enemies. Lacking the third dimension of a dark souls game, enemies are rarely avoidable and attempting to do so is liable to land you in the incredibly common and immediately deadly aforementioned spikes. So you don't get to run back to where you died, you instead get to clear the entire area again, isn't that fun?

Apparently there's fast travel. I got annoyed and quit well before I unlocked it, and you can only upgrade at the main city. So if you want to use your currency you have to run back through every zone you've gone through so far to do so. You do get shortcuts back through these zones, but it's still a hell of a trek a lot of the time.

In summary: there's so many other games out there with better platforming and better quality of life. There's harder games if your goal is bragging rights. The only thing Blasphemous is unbeatable on is style and aesthetic. If you *really* love those about this game then sure play it. As for me, experiencing the gameplay actually made me like it a lot less. Go watch someone else play it and admire it from afar.

145018024.review:
The artstyle, music, voice acting and atmosphere are all great. But I have one major gripe with the game.

I was replaying it for the new content, most of which I would only get to see in my NG+. The crux of the matter however is while you get to keep your Prayers/Relics/Beads/Mea Culpa upgrades, for whatever reason you are having your HP/Fervour/Knot/Flask upgrades be reset to 0 upon entering NG+. Wait, what? Why? It is completely unnecessary and it adds nothing to the experience except putting a tedious collect-a-thon in the way of wrapping up the actually meaningful content you didn't get to see the first time. NG+ is already considerably harder and has Penitences if you so desire. Why do I need to go through the whole game and collect all the upgrades I already found AGAIN before I can tackle the actual content I started NG+ for in the first place? No  Souls, Souls-like or basically any other game with NG+ would make such an unfun design decision.

Imagine in Elden Ring the developers randomly decide you keep your spells and spirit ashes, but you need to collect all the flask upgrades, recipe books and grind runes to level up your Vigor/HP and Mind/FP all over again from scratch in every NG+ cycle. Gee, that sounds like such a fun concept, I wonder why no one else ever tried this. 

And the thing is you NEED NG+ to experience all the new content (and to get the true ending, which you VERY likely don't get in NG since it is VERY missable).

These design decisions are completely killing my motivation to see the new content, because it is simply unnecessarily tedious to access. Make the DLC accessible in the first run and the true ending less missable like in Hollow Knight. Or just let me keep my stuff. Having both at once is just bad game design to me. I feel like a lot of people are gona miss it entirely because it is too inconvenient to bother with.

144925146.review:
I originally played Blasphemous on console, and I really liked the lore and art direction that the game took so I wanted to revisit on the PC.

For whatever reason, I found the PC port to have significantly more bugs than the console such as enemies randomly glitching through the backgrounds which then prevented me from proceeding which resulted in resetting the game and progress which was incredibly frustrating. Path finding issues as well felt more prolific such as grabbing onto ledges and falling to my death.

The game is extremely unforgiving in my view, you make one small error in trying to speed through an area and this can ultimately cost you to back track significantly, particularly with the layout of some areas being horrific.

As others have mentioned as well, you will inevitably at some point need to look at a guide for your first run to progress, even having played this on console the first time I often ran around aimlessly, resorting at looking at a guide which often killed the immersion. 

For all of Blasphemous flaws, in my mind it's still worth picking up on sale for it's unique art and lore, and this is coming from someone who ultimately sucks at platformers. 

Hopefully Blasphemous 2 picks up on the foundations the original game started and improves.

144923832.review:
Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas es un videojuego de acción-aventura de mundo abierto desarrollado por Rockstar North y publicado por Rockstar Games. Fue confirmado oficialmente por la mencionada Rockstar Games a principios de marzo de 2004, y su fecha de lanzamiento tentativa se programó para el 19 y 22 de octubre de ese año para América del Norte y Europa.
La trama del juego ocurre en San Andreas, estado ficticio que contiene a tres ciudades metropolitanas: Los Santos, San Fierro y Las Venturas; las tres basadas en las ciudades de Los Ángeles, San Francisco y Las Vegas, respectivamente, siendo el segundo mapa más extenso de la saga detrás de GTA V. Ambientado en 1992, la obra cuenta la historia de Carl Johnson “CJ”, quien decide volver a Los Santos tras cinco años de haberse ausentado en Liberty City —ciudad de otros videojuegos de la saga como GTA III, GTA Liberty City Stories o GTA IV— después de enterarse del asesinato de su madre. Al llegar, CJ intenta restablecer el poder de su antigua banda y su familia, mientras desvela poco a poco la verdad detrás de la muerte de su madre. Su trama se basa libremente en sucesos como la rivalidad entre las pandillas Bloods y Crips, la epidemia de crack, el escándalo Rampart y los disturbios de Los Ángeles de 1992.

144907686.review:
(Have completed my first playthrough, but not much more)

So, when I first played this game, I bounced off hard, something about the platforming and the combat weren't jiving with each other or with me, but I tried again a few weeks later, and honestly overall this is an excellent game. There are big issues with the game not explaining itself however, notably in the post-game. For example, beating the game unlocks a boss rush mode and new game+, but nothing tells you the boss rush mode is a boss rush mode unless you go through old patch notes, and I literally had to google search how to NG+ because I'm an idiot, but also it's a little vague. I'm cool with the lore and game mechanics being a little opaque, but I feel meta-mechanisms like the above should be clearer.

Also, wow when the game warns you that NG+ is significantly harder it is not joking. Not bad, but notable. This game tends to get noted as "soulslike", and while the base game didn't feel fully that way, the post-game definitely does.

There's some definite quirky-ness to the platforming. You can't grab a ledge unless you're lined up near-perfectly and facing the right way, if you're too close you won't grab it, where in most games there's not really a "too close". And ladders! You can't grab them unless you're lined up almost perfectly with the center. Again, once you know it, you adjust to it, but it's notable because I've never noticed similar things in other games. 

Boss fights are very memorable even when I found them easy. Hilariously, the hardest times I'd have were when I'd forget that basic mechanics like blocking existed. I looked up a youtube video at one point and stopped after 5 seconds feeling like an idiot.

I'd recommend this to anyone who really liked Hollow Knight or similar titles, it's a fun time, but if you don't like combat-heavy platformers, you'll probably not like this one either. Additionally, the Spanish Catholic influences are notable only because while I was never bothered, I can definitely understand why deeply religious people would find this off-putting or even offensive. Sort of a buyer beware there.

Additionally, minor spoiler, but I totally thought I was heading for the "true" ending, and in-game it seemed like I had done everything I had needed to, but then I got the bad ending? Primarily I think because the true ending was added in a post-game DLC and assumes you have gotten/know how to get the "good" ending as a basis. Just a little jarring, tbh.

144899331.review:
TL;DR: Art and combat good, platforming not so much

Not gonna lie, the first 1 hour didn't really impress me well. But the more I played (and getting good), it's actually a great game. The combat is quite satisfying once you're used to it. The enemies and environment style is also very great looking. If I'm gonna rate just the content for the main game, it's a solid 7.5/10.

If I have to nitpick something that's not implemented well enough, I would say it's the platforming side quest (or just platforming in general). Although it's not a problem for most of the game because you can probably cheese it with some technique. BUT it's a different matter when talking about the Miriam's side quest. Simply put it's a timed platform challenge. And some levels had actually a moving platform that made you sit on it for a damn long time while it delivers you to a shooting fireballs. At that point it's not even a bullet hell anymore, it's just an HP endurance challenge. Why bother with a timer when you can't avoid a moving platform with 40 seconds of linear path (I don't actually counted it but feels like it). The platform foothold is also very weird, you can clip through the moving platform if you got hit by a fireball. Lastly is probably the lantern dash strike thing (idk what to call it) where the game never gave a tutorial on how to do it, and if you hit the lantern at exactly the handle of the sword it won't even register and you'll just fall to your death. I completed all of it, but didn't get the same sense of accomplishment like other platformers (give me achievement please). Again not a problem for most of the game, only for the platforming section.

144877091.review:
My love-hate relationship with metroidvanias continues in Blasphemous, another much-loved entry in the genre. Once again, the devs created a fantastic atmosphere with great audiovisuals, added superb world-building and wrote a slightly opaque but still very enjoyable story. Blasphemous is about pain and penance in a world founded on a distorted religion - and penance makes its way into every aspect of the game. Unfortunately, that includes the controls, the platforming challenges and the combat - I certainly had opportunity to repent a lot for my sins while I was grappling with a movement system that was neither precise nor fluent, a combat system where any mob could insta-kill you any time by pushing you off inconvenient ledges, and the huge amount of backtracking on a map that is in itself brilliant but needs lots of traversing as the game gives you so little clue to go on.
It's hard for me to recommend the game, and equally hard not to recommend. There's a lot of value in it, but there's too much time in it when it's simply not fun. Since I managed to atone my way through the world of Blasphemous, I'll give it a thumbs up, but my recommendation is to try the demo first.

This game is all about parrying. Even attacks you can't counter attack, you only get knocked back (with juicy iframes), and will never fall off a ledge after a successful parry. The pixel art, move set, level and enemy/boss design is all top tier, absolutely excellent. Every single boss is tough, but fair (excluding the last boss, he's a cake walk). 

My only con for this game would be all the backtracking, however, there is teleporting between save points provided you donate 20k to the church, as well as a spell that will take you to your last save point.

I got this on sale, but honestly, I would have paid full price, this game is incredible and even has a ton of replay value thanks to the devs making so many updates. Can't wait to play the sequel tomorrow!

144824819.review:
Very cool game with a cool atmosphere and world. The story is a bit confusing but it kinda reminds me of Dark Souls, telling the lore through item descriptions and such. I really haven't played many Metroidvania games before this one and it honestly didn't disappoint. The progression was challenging but rewarding, the enemies were difficult yet balanced, and the secrets were very well hidden (sometimes so well I needed the wiki). 

But the parkour. Oh my God the parkour. Don't get me started on the platforming. Spike pits that are insta-kill if you even look at them funny. Map hazards with so much knockback it makes it seem like the beatings I get from my drunken father are no more than gusts of wind. Ladders that sometimes just don't even let you climb on them, leading to many, many painfully simple deaths. And sometimes the game just decides that you can't move anymore, so that's fun.

I have more to say but I'll sum up: Do I recommend the game? Yes. Do I like the game's mechanics? Definitely yes. Is exploration fun? See the above paragraph. 

Just don't do the Strife & Ruin challenges and you'll be alright!

144823542.review:
It's an extremely rich world filled with lore and interesting characters backed up by great voice work. 

Combat has a lot left to be desired, after meeting most enemies and bosses, they're all pretty straight forward and easy to beat. The DLC-boss content added a lot of difficulty to the game which is super nice. 

If you're looking to complete the game and get the true ending I'd recommend looking up a quick tutorial to see the checklist needed in order to obtain that so that you're not locked into a specific ending while you're deep deep into your campaign.

144812401.review: A great game well worth the money especially with the free updates. An extremely solid Metroidvania with a beautiful art style, great music, and fluid gameplay. Tons of side quests and extra things on the side to keep you entertained throughout. New game plus and boss rush mode also help extend the play time. If I could describe the gameplay in one word it would be satisfying. The executions are brutal and fun to pull off. The combat is fluid and great. The enemies have great designs and all have different patterns to memorize. The bosses are incredible and are a blast to adapt and conquer. Their designs have a great warped monster feel that intimidate you. All areas of the combat and abilities have great depth and multitudes of options. Barely any complaints other than the game itself being somewhat vague in terms of gameplay and story. Be prepared to look up certain things  as there are a decent amount of stuff that gets overlooked in a first play through, but maybe that’s where the beauty of multiple play throughs  come in. The bosses do seem to come out of nowhere to me and I would’ve liked a little more build up, but that’s just me. The atmosphere and world it tries to build up is intriguing and breathtaking  but they seem to give a lot of questions and it leaves a good bit up to the player for interpretation.  I wanted to know the backstory how everything happened and there was just times I felt I was not being shown as much as I wanted. And while the final boss is great both endings felt slightly underwhelming and too cryptic, which is a fitting word for the story in general. Overall, I would definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys metroidvanias or a challenging video game with a great style. And while the story is a little too vague for my liking, the pros EASILY outweigh the cons. What’s great is REALLY GREAT and the cons are really just tiny nitpicks that don’t really dampen the experience a lot at all. For the price this game is a no-brainer for the enjoyment you’ll get. I cannot recommend enough.

I originally got introduced to this game via PS4 and I played it for like 2 days and forgot about it. Noticed it was on sale after not thinking about it in like 7 months. It's been so much fun, and I honestly prefer to play via keyboard and mouse but that's just my preference. 
Art is absolutely stunning. It fits the vibe they were going for perfectly. All monsters I've seen so far are all aesthetically pleasing to the eye and are scaled well difficulty wise. Difficulty scaling of my play through this far has been a breath of fresh air. It's hard, but not so hard that you can't get past it. It isn't too harsh on deaths either which was nice. The bosses I've fought so far have been difficult but not to where I had to give up the game. I'm currently stuck on an optional boss, but if I push myself I can beat her. I honestly think my favorite part about this game has to be the secrets and puzzles. While not being super ground breaking, I loved that some puzzles where placed in earlier areas of the game so then you come back to them, making many areas in the game re-playable which I really enjoyed. This game so far has made me really look forward to the upcoming sequel and you'll be sure I'm buying it once I have money lol. I'd recommend this game any day, I'd give it a solid 9.7/10

144769890.review:
This is going to sound absolutely insane, but, this game genuinely helped me get through a very serious issue I have with myself. There's a mechanic in this game where you can gain "guilt" when you die, but you can visit these giant statues that you can bow before and they will absolve you. If you don't have any though, it will simply tell you, "You are rid of guilt." 

And it just... clicked. The statue in question is in the pose of forgiving you, and somehow my weird brain internalized that. I bowed before the statue, and I am rid of my guilt. You have no idea how good that feels.. Now when I start to feel bad, I close my eyes, and I bow. And I am rid of guilt. 

No more hating myself for stupid little things, no more constant pain in my head. My heart feels so good right now. I can't even describe how amazing and life changing this is. And all from some random little in game moment out of nowhere my weird stupid brain decided to just, keep. 

I'm free... I'm finally free. And I can't stop crying tears of joy. thank you. Thank you.. Thank you.. thank you.

144683124.review:
TLDR: An excellent game for those who enjoy metroidvania genres and an eerie "dark soul-like" theme.

To simplify, think of it as a fusion between Metroidvania and Dark Souls. Rather than guiding you with straightforward quest logs, the game weaves its story through items and hushed messages found on certain remains, akin to the approach in the Dark Souls series. The game's difficulty ranges from "challenging but fair" to "highly demanding," a spectrum that I find incredibly satisfying. I remember struggling against one of the DLC bosses (whom I won't spoil by naming), initially leading to frustration. However, mastering the art of parrying turned the tides. The battle, albeit brief, became an immensely enjoyable experience, without needing to rely on overpowered tactics often showcased by YouTuber peasants for sloppy victories.

Unlike in Metroid Fusion, defeating bosses doesn't directly grant upgrades for your gear or abilities. Instead, these enhancements are scattered throughout the world and some tied to indirect quests from various NPCs. The game's essence lies in exploration, making it a pivotal aspect for your progression. On the downside, there are a few drawbacks to mention. The roster of bosses is somewhat limited, and the act of conquering a boss doesn't yield a distinct reward. Furthermore, the array of enemies could use more variety. Completing the Miriam challenges or minigames can be vexing, and regrettably, the rewards post-completion are not particularly noteworthy but rather absent.

It's important to note that the game offers three distinct endings. Be cautious, as you could unintentionally prevent yourself from achieving one of these endings by entering a room linked to one of the final bosses, even if these bosses are not immediately visible upon moving to the next room. A word of advice: if you're aiming for the ending that necessitates possession of two in-game items, refrain from using the three-headed elevator until you've successfully obtained and placed these two items in their designated locations. I personally made the error of continuing my exploration, which unfortunately resulted in locking myself out of that specific ending.

I encourage you to give this game a try; I can assure you that you'll likely find as much enjoyment in it as I did. No game is a "masterpiece", but this one was close to being one. I'm eagerly anticipating the release of the game's sequel, as I believe it holds the potential to build upon the foundation laid by its predecessor. 

----Pros-----
- Dark souls + metroidvania. 
- Gloomy atmosphere (story and environment) 
- Hard Content
- Superb Voice Acting (English and Spanish)
- Smooth gameplay 
- beautiful artstyle
- 3 endings, Endings are tightly affected by the *indirect* choices you make

----Cons----

- Poor mob variety
- Not enough bosses

144602175.review:
Janky ledges, janky grabs, janky knockback makes this a platforming nightmare.

The mechanic of sticking to certain walls by your shoving your sword in is great; until you have to do it in combat where you either jump off to hit the enemy and cannot cling back on, or jump off to hit the enemy and your swing sticks you back onto the wall. It is very unintuitive and poorly implemented.

The platforming challenges might as well be ripped straight out of a kaizo Mario hack, only you don't have anything close to the solid Mario mechanics.

Combat, art and music are all great in spite of that, but I wouldn't recommend this game based solely on the platforming alone.

144597591.review:
Oh, let me tell you about Blasphemous! It's a dark and twisted action-platformer that's a feast for fans of challenging gameplay and atmospheric storytelling. Developed by The Game Kitchen, this game immerses you in a macabre world inspired by Spanish folklore and religious imagery.

The first thing that strikes you is the stunning pixel art style. The visuals are incredibly detailed, with intricate animations and beautifully designed environments. Every corner of the game is dripping with grotesque and haunting art that adds to the eerie atmosphere.

Gameplay-wise, Blasphemous delivers tight and responsive controls, which are crucial for a game that demands precision platforming and combat. The combat system offers a satisfying variety of weapons and abilities that can be upgraded and customized to suit your playstyle. The boss battles are particularly noteworthy, offering challenging encounters that require strategy and skill to overcome.

One of the game's strongest aspects is its narrative. Blasphemous tells a cryptic and disturbing story through its world, characters, and collectibles. Every interaction and discovery adds to the lore, leaving players intrigued and hungry for more insight into the game's dark universe.

However, keep in mind that the difficulty level might be a turnoff for some players. The game doesn't hold back in challenging you, often requiring precise timing and execution. This can lead to moments of frustration, but the feeling of accomplishment when you finally conquer a tough section is worth it.

In a nutshell, if you're a fan of challenging action-platformers with a captivating and grim narrative, Blasphemous is right up your alley. The game's stunning art style, tight gameplay, and haunting atmosphere create an experience that's both visually striking and emotionally engaging. Just be prepared for a journey that tests your skills and patience as you navigate through a world steeped in dark fantasy and lore.

It stands out amongst its peers due to its thoroughly macabre setting (basically Grim-Dark Fantasy Inspired By Medieval Spanish Catholicism Cranked Up To 11), which is further amplified by its fantastic soundtrack. 144549768.review: Great art, gameplay was actually pretty fun for a while. However, there are much better games out there. Controls are clunky; game physics feel like they're done by a high school student. You die more often to platforms (wonky hitbox) and ladders not 'catching'. Also, just found out that cloud saves don't sync between Steam Deck and PC. Incompetent devs, but kudos to the art direction.

144546456.review:
This game is probably one of my most favourite 2D games ever. I've been in love with the dark-fantasy genre of games and stories due to their depth and designs, Blasphemous put all of that into a hispanic-christianity setting.
I've never been so addicted to a 2D metroidvania game in a long time, the game mechanics can be quite fun as you progress and it just keeps getting better. The open-world aspect is also a cool feature, of course sometimes you would sometimes forget to set your most recent spawn. 

Overall: This game is perfect for people who love metroidvania, 2D platforms and such, Soulsborne, and those familiar/interested with the hispanic-christianity traditions of old.

144535921.review:
[h1] Metroidvania with a horrifying concept on Miracles [/h1] 
[I] “I wonder what’s going inside the Art Director’s head when he made this.” [/i] 
[hr][/hr]

[I] Blasphemous [/i] caught my attention when it reminded me of similar games like [I] Castlevania [/i], and how it’s talked along with [I] Bloodstained [/i]. So, I had my expectations high, and it delivered, the world of Blasphemous is horrifying and intriguing that it just makes you want to play more and find out more around this world. Characters, cutscenes, and Voice add more that it can make you play again, and the developers know and gives you more content to play around and achievements to achieve. 

For the base game, it’s an open-world, you are given quest locations that you can do in any order but certain quests can be missable, making you either load your previous save or create a whole new game, choices are permanent and sometimes the smallest actions can create a huge difference to how NPCs will end up, some only impacts the side quests but some can lock you out from achieving a certain ending. 

The choices you make, doing side quests, collecting collectibles reward you. You can see [I] Albedo [/i] improve as you continue to help them, certain NPCs reward and/or improve your character making things easier than the trouble you went through made it easier for later. 

I highly suggest using an interactive map, tracking collectibles and guiding where they are, the map is huge, and you might get lost going where next or lose count on how far you’ve progressed collecting. 

With that said, with such a huge map, every time you enter a new area or approaching a boss, it felt foreboding because the enemies and bosses you’ve went through were horrifying and grim that makes you say [I] “What the fuck” [/i] makes you more intrigued what this new area has in store for you. The music is amazing that you can feel how scary fighting against these enemies. 

[hr][/hr] 
[h2] DLCs / Extra Content [/h2]
[hr][/hr]
For extra content or the DLCs in this game, they are certain DLCs that were more of a hit or miss to me. [I] Wounds of Evertide [/i] is an extra content which adds a lot in the game, and just makes the game all the better, the bosses, the enemies, the music, I couldn’t forget how much fun I had fighting them and how many times I have died fighting them. 

[I] Strife & Ruin [/i] was the most infuriating moment I had in this entire game. Learning there was a collaboration with [I] Bloodstained [/i], I was expecting a playable character, an interesting boss fight but all it gave me was just LADDERS. Well, it’s a Time Trial that mostly consists of ladders and spikes, and thanks the miracle that this is completely optional, that it is not needed to complete on getting 100% of the game because I quit pursuing this quest halfway through because on how much I hated it.  

And the rewards seemed disappointing when I looked it up, all the trouble just to get a Prayer. 

[I] Stir of Dawn [/i] is the extra content I have yet to review, perhaps if I have the extra free time, I can rewrite this review and talk about this, but as far as I know, this is the New Game+ content of the game. 

[hr][/hr] 
[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
[hr][/hr]
Overall, it is one of the best Metroid-Vania games with lots of replayability and lots of challenges for you to complete. Buy it on sale or on full price, it’s one of the must-haves of Singleplayer games.

144530978.review:
Aside from the Rose mirror quests where some ladders are an absolute nightmare to climb. Grinding the game out proved to be enjoyable. Which is more than can be said for the second release version of this game franchise (Blasphemous 2).
There is definitely a lot more flexibility on this title compared to the second one and the difficulty scaling is fairly correctly balanced throughout. Great story with plenty of side quests and exploration.
